summary.en: “Cong” is most often seen as an uncommon shorthand for “congrats,” an abbreviation for “Congress” (Cong.), or a Vietnamese given name.
summary.zh: “Cong”最常见的用法是（较少见的）“congrats”的简写、表示“Congress（国会）”的缩写（Cong.），或作为越南人名。

definition.en: (informal, texting) A shortened form of “congrats / congratulations.” (Less common than “congrats.”)
definition.zh: （非正式、短信用语）“congrats / congratulations（恭喜）”的缩写形式。（不如“congrats”常见）

examples.en: Cong! You passed the exam.
examples.zh: Cong！你考试通过了。

examples.en: Cong on your new job!
examples.zh: Cong你找到新工作啦！

definition.en: (often written “Cong.”) Abbreviation for “Congress” in some contexts (especially titles, references, or notes).
definition.zh: （常写作“Cong.”）在某些语境中是“Congress（国会）”的缩写（多见于标题、引用或注释）。

examples.en: See the report submitted to Cong. in 2024.
examples.zh: 参见2024年提交给Cong.（国会）的报告。

examples.en: He worked as a staffer on Capitol Hill (in Cong.).
examples.zh: 他曾在国会山工作（在Cong.）。

definition.en: A Vietnamese given name (often from “Công”), used as a personal name in English writing.
definition.zh: 越南语人名（常源自“Công”），在英文中作为姓名拼写出现。

examples.en: Cong Nguyen will present the project today.
examples.zh: Cong Nguyen 今天将展示这个项目。

examples.en: I met Cong at a conference in Hanoi.
examples.zh: 我在河内的一个会议上认识了Cong。

extraExplanation: 在英文里单独写“Cong”比较少见：表达“恭喜”更常用“Congrats!”；表达“国会”更常见直接写“Congress”或在正式资料里用“Cong.”。
作为越南人名时，“Cong”通常来自越南语“Công”（常与“功、工、功绩/劳动”等含义相关），英文中为方便输入可能省略声调。

summary.en: “Cong” most commonly refers (historically, informally) to the Viet Cong; it can also be a surname or an abbreviation for “Congress.”
summary.zh: “Cong”最常见（历史、非正式）指“越共”；也可作姓氏，或作“Congress（国会）”的缩写。

definition.en: (informal, historical) A member of the Viet Cong (the communist-led guerrilla force in South Vietnam during the Vietnam War).
definition.zh: （非正式、历史用语）越共成员（越南战争时期南越的共产主义领导的游击力量成员）。

examples.en: Some war-era films refer to enemy fighters as “the Cong.”
examples.zh: 一些战争年代的电影会把敌方战斗人员称作“the Cong（越共）”。

examples.en: The term appears in older news reports about the Vietnam War.
examples.zh: 这个词常出现在关于越南战争的旧新闻报道中。

definition.en: A family name (surname), found in several cultures (e.g., Vietnamese/Chinese communities).
definition.zh: 一个姓氏，在一些文化中可见（例如越南/华人社群）。

examples.en: Ms. Cong will present the report today.
examples.zh: Cong 女士今天将做报告。

definition.en: An abbreviation used in some contexts for “congress” or “congressional.”
definition.zh: （缩写）在某些语境中表示“国会”或“国会的”。

examples.en: The memo uses “Cong.” to mean “Congress.”
examples.zh: 这份备忘录用“Cong.”表示“Congress（国会）”。

extraExplanation: “the Cong”主要是越南战争时期英语里的口语/军中用法，带有明显时代色彩；在当代语境中可能显得粗略甚至冒犯。更中性、更准确的说法通常是“Viet Cong”或“the National Liberation Front (NLF)”。
如果你想表达中文拼音“cōng（葱/聪/从等）”或越南语人名“Công”，请告诉我具体语境（句子或你想表达的意思），我可以帮你对应到正确的英文词。

summary.en: “Conga” most commonly means a lively Afro-Cuban dance (often in a line) or a tall hand drum used in Latin music.
summary.zh: “conga”常指热烈的古巴康加舞（常排成一列）或拉丁音乐中使用的康加鼓。

definition.en: a lively Afro-Cuban dance (often done in a line) and the music for it, common at parties and celebrations
definition.zh: 康加舞（常排成一列的热烈古巴舞）及其音乐，常见于派对和庆典

examples.en: At the wedding, everyone joined the conga line around the room.
examples.zh: 在婚礼上，大家都加入了康加舞队列，绕着房间跳。

examples.en: The band played conga music and the crowd started clapping to the beat.
examples.zh: 乐队演奏康加音乐，人群跟着节拍拍手。

definition.en: a tall, narrow drum used in Latin music, played with the hands
definition.zh: 康加鼓（一种拉丁音乐中常用的高而窄的手鼓）

examples.en: She learned basic rhythms on the conga.
examples.zh: 她学会了康加鼓的基本节奏。

examples.en: You can hear the conga clearly in salsa songs.
examples.zh: 在萨尔萨歌曲里你能清楚听到康加鼓的声音。

extraExplanation: “conga”与古巴的黑人文化传统关系密切，后来在拉丁音乐（如salsa）中非常常见；派对里常说“conga line（康加舞队列）”，大家一边走一边跳，通常扶着前一个人的肩。

summary.en: “congaed” is a nonstandard past tense meaning “danced the conga.”
summary.zh: “congaed”是“conga”的非标准过去式，表示“跳了康加舞”。

definition.en: Nonstandard past tense of “conga” (to do the conga dance), meaning “danced the conga.”
definition.zh: “conga”（跳康加舞）的非标准过去式，意思是“跳了康加舞”。

examples.en: We congaed around the room at the wedding reception.
examples.zh: 我们在婚礼宴会上围着房间跳康加舞。

examples.en: They congaed in a long line, laughing the whole time.
examples.zh: 他们排成一长列跳康加舞，全程都在笑。

extraExplanation: “congaed”在拼写上不太常见，很多写法会用“congaed”或更口语/非正式的“conga’d”。在正式写作里，更自然的表达常是：“did the conga”或“danced the conga”。
“conga”本来是舞蹈/音乐名（源自拉丁音乐文化），英语里把它当动词使用多见于轻松、派对语境。

summary.en: “Congaing” means dancing the conga, usually in a conga line; it’s an uncommon, informal spelling.
summary.zh: “congaing”指跳康加舞（常为康加舞队），但这种拼写较少见、偏非正式。

definition.en: Informal/nonstandard spelling of the present participle of “conga,” meaning dancing the conga (often in a conga line).
definition.zh: “conga”的现在分词的非正式/不规范拼写，意思是跳康加舞（常指排成“康加舞队”一起跳）。

examples.en: We ended up congaing around the room after dinner.
examples.zh: 晚饭后我们最后在房间里排成队跳起了康加舞。

examples.en: They were congaing in a long line at the wedding reception.
examples.zh: 他们在婚宴上排着长队跳康加舞。

extraExplanation: “congaing”在现实写作里比较少见，更常见的表达是“dancing the conga”或“doing the conga / a conga line”。如果你是在正式场合写作，建议用这些更常见、更自然的说法。
“conga”原本指一种源自古巴、带有非洲节奏影响的舞蹈与音乐形式；在英语文化里，“conga line（康加舞队）”常出现在派对、婚礼等热闹场合，大家排成一列跟着音乐走动、摆动。

summary.en: Congas are tall hand drums used in Afro-Cuban and Latin music.
summary.zh: Congas 指用于非裔古巴与拉丁音乐的高筒形手鼓（康加鼓）。

definition.en: A set of tall, narrow drums (usually played in pairs or a small group) used in Afro-Cuban and Latin music, played with the hands.
definition.zh: 康加鼓；一种高而窄的手鼓（常成对或成组演奏），常用于非裔古巴与拉丁音乐。

examples.en: The percussionist played congas during the salsa song.
examples.zh: 那位打击乐手在萨尔萨歌曲中演奏康加鼓。

examples.en: You can hear the congas clearly in the chorus.
examples.zh: 你在副歌里能清楚听到康加鼓的声音。

extraExplanation: “congas”通常是复数形式，指一组康加鼓；单数为“conga”。
康加鼓和“bongos（邦戈鼓）”不同：conga更高更大，音色更低沉厚实；bongo较小，常夹在膝间演奏，音色更明亮。
常见搭配：conga drums（康加鼓）、play the congas（打康加鼓）、conga rhythm/beat（康加节奏）。

summary.en: Congdon is most commonly an English-language surname; it can also appear as a place name.
summary.zh: Congdon 最常见为英语姓氏；也可作较少见的地名。

definition.en: a family name (surname) of English origin
definition.zh: （英裔常见的）姓氏：康登 / 孔登（多用于人名）

examples.en: Ms. Congdon will lead the meeting today.
examples.zh: 康登女士今天将主持会议。

examples.en: I met Dr. Congdon at a conference.
examples.zh: 我在一次会议上见到了康登博士。

definition.en: a place name (less common), used in some English-speaking regions as a name for roads, neighborhoods, or landmarks
definition.zh: （较少见）地名：在一些英语地区可用作道路、社区或地标的名称

examples.en: The library is near Congdon Avenue.
examples.zh: 图书馆在康登大道附近。

examples.en: They live in the Congdon neighborhood.
examples.zh: 他们住在康登社区。

extraExplanation: “Congdon”多见于英语国家的人名（姓）。作为姓氏时，通常不翻译含义而是音译（如“康登/孔登”），具体译法会因地区与个人偏好而不同。
英语里读姓氏时一般重音在第一音节：CONG-don。遇到不确定的姓氏读音，最礼貌的做法是直接询问对方：“How do you pronounce your last name?”

summary.en: Congé means formal permission to leave or a leave of absence, and it is rare in modern everyday English.
summary.zh: congé 指正式的“准许离开”或“休假/告假”，在现代日常英语中较少见。

definition.en: formal permission to leave; a leave of absence (now rare in everyday English).
definition.zh: （正式用语）准许离开；休假、告假（现代日常英语中较少见）。

examples.en: After the meeting, she asked the chair for her congé.
examples.zh: 会议结束后，她向主持人请求准许离开。

examples.en: The officer was granted congé for a family emergency.
examples.zh: 那名军官因家庭紧急情况获准休假。

extraExplanation: “congé”来自法语，原意与“休假/许可离开”有关，在英式或较正式、历史性的语境中偶尔出现（如军队、官场、旧文体）。现代更常用的表达是：leave, permission to leave, time off。
注意别和“congee（粥，米粥）”混淆；两者拼写和读音相近，但意思完全不同。

summary.en: “Congeable” means ‘able to congeal/solidify,’ but it’s rare; “congealable” is the common form.
summary.zh: “congeable”意为“可凝固/可凝结的”，但用法罕见；更常用的形式是“congealable”。

definition.en: Able to congeal (to become semi-solid or solid, especially when cooled), or able to be made to congeal.
definition.zh: 可凝结的；可凝固的（尤指冷却后变得半固体或固体，或可被使之凝固）。

examples.en: The sauce is congeable, so it will thicken as it cools.
examples.zh: 这酱汁是可凝固的，所以冷却后会变稠。

examples.en: Use a little gelatin if you want the mixture to be more congeable.
examples.zh: 如果你想让混合物更容易凝固，可以加一点明胶。

definition.en: (Rare/Nonstandard) Used as a variant of “congealable.” In modern English, “congealable” is much more common.
definition.zh: （少见/不太规范）有时被当作“congealable（可凝固的）”的变体；现代英语中“congealable”更常用。

examples.en: This term is more often written as congealable in recipes and scientific writing.
examples.zh: 在食谱和科学写作中，这个词更常写作 congealable。

extraExplanation: “congeable”在当代英语里很少见，许多词典不收或标为罕用。学习与写作时更推荐用 congealable（可凝固的）或直接用动词 congeal（凝结/凝固）。
词根来自拉丁语 con-（一起）+ gelare（冻结），与 gel（凝胶）、gelatin（明胶）同源。

summary.en: Congeal means to become thick/solid (especially when cooling) or to make ideas or support become unified and clear.
summary.zh: congeal 指（液体）因冷却而凝结变稠/变硬，也可指（比喻）使想法、计划或支持凝聚成形、变得统一清晰。

definition.en: (Of a liquid) to become thick or solid, often because it cools.
definition.zh: （液体）凝结、变稠或变成固体，常因冷却而发生。

examples.en: The gravy will congeal if you leave it out too long.
examples.zh: 肉汁如果在外面放太久会凝结变稠。

examples.en: Blood can congeal quickly in cold weather.
examples.zh: 在寒冷天气里，血液可能很快凝结。

definition.en: To make something form into a solid or a unified whole (often used metaphorically).
definition.zh: 使某物凝结成形；（常作比喻）使观点、计划或团体成形并统一起来。

examples.en: After several meetings, their ideas began to congeal into a clear plan.
examples.zh: 开了几次会后，他们的想法开始凝聚成一个清晰的计划。

examples.en: The crisis helped congeal public support for reform.
examples.zh: 这场危机促使公众对改革的支持凝聚起来。

extraExplanation: “congeal”常见搭配：congeal into（凝结/凝聚成……），congeal around（围绕……凝聚）。
比喻用法很常见，强调“从散乱到成形/成体系”的过程，语气比“form”更带“逐渐变得固定”的感觉。
词源来自拉丁语，和“gel（凝胶）”同源，因此常用于描述像油脂、汤汁、血液这类会变稠或变硬的物质。

summary.en: Congealability means how able something is to congeal—thicken or become solid, usually when cooled.
summary.zh: Congealability 指某物“能否/多容易凝结或凝固”，通常与冷却后变稠或变硬有关。

definition.en: the ability of a substance to congeal (to thicken or become solid, especially when cooled)
definition.zh: （物质）可凝结性；可凝固性（尤指冷却后变稠或变硬的能力）

examples.en: The congealability of the sauce depends on how much fat and gelatin it contains.
examples.zh: 这酱汁的可凝结性取决于它含有多少脂肪和明胶。

examples.en: Scientists tested the oil’s congealability at low temperatures.
examples.zh: 科学家测试了这种油在低温下的凝固倾向。

extraExplanation: “congealability”是由 congeal（凝结/凝固）+ -ability（……的能力）构成的名词，常见于食品科学、化学、材料测试等语境。日常英语里更常说“how easily it congeals / solidifies（它多容易凝固）”。

summary.en: Congealable describes something that can become solid or semi-solid when it cools.
summary.zh: congealable 指“可凝结的”，即物质冷却后会变成固体或半固体。

definition.en: Able to become solid (or semi-solid) when cooled.
definition.zh: 可凝结的；可因冷却而变硬（或半固化）的。

examples.en: Coconut oil is congealable at cooler room temperatures.
examples.zh: 椰子油在较凉的室温下会凝固。

examples.en: Use a container that can handle hot liquid that later becomes congealable.
examples.zh: 使用能装热液体、且之后会凝固的容器。

extraExplanation: “Congealable”来自动词“congeal”（凝结、凝固），常用于描述油脂（fat/oil）、酱汁（gravy/sauce）、血液（blood）等在降温后变稠或变硬的性质。
在烹饪语境中，它常暗示“冷却后会结成一层”或“会变成果冻状/凝脂状”，例如汤放凉后表面出现的脂肪层。
相关词对比：solidify更偏“变成固体”的一般说法；congeal更强调从液态变稠、凝结成团或半固态的过程。

summary.en: Congealableness means a substance’s ability to congeal—thicken or become solid, often when cooled.
summary.zh: Congealableness 指物质“可凝结性”，即能变稠或变成固体（常因冷却）。

definition.en: the quality or ability of a substance to congeal (to thicken or become solid, especially when cooled)
definition.zh: （物质的）可凝结性；可（因冷却等）变稠或变成固体的性质

examples.en: The congealableness of the fat increases in colder weather, so it turns solid quickly.
examples.zh: 天气更冷时，脂肪的可凝结性更明显，所以很快就会变成固体。

examples.en: They tested the congealableness of different sauces to see which would coat the food best.
examples.zh: 他们测试了不同酱汁的可凝结性，看看哪一种最能均匀裹住食物。

extraExplanation: 这个词非常少见，多用于技术或较正式的描述；日常英语更常说 congealability、ability to congeal，或直接用形容词 congealable（“可凝结的”）。
构词提示：congeal（凝结）+ -able（能……的）+ -ness（……的性质）→ congealableness（“能凝结的性质/程度”）。

summary.en: Congealed means thickened or partly solidified, usually after cooling; it’s also the past form of “congeal.”
summary.zh: congealed 指（多因冷却而）变稠、凝固的；也可作 congeal 的过去式/过去分词。

definition.en: Having become thick, semi-solid, or firm (often from cooling), so it no longer flows easily.
definition.zh: （常因冷却而）凝固的、变稠成半固体的，不再容易流动的。

examples.en: The gravy congealed as it cooled on the table.
examples.zh: 肉汁在桌上变凉后就凝固了。

examples.en: There was a layer of congealed fat on top of the soup.
examples.zh: 汤上面有一层凝固的油脂。

definition.en: Past tense/past participle of “congeal”: to become thick or solid; to cause something to thicken or solidify.
definition.zh: “congeal”的过去式/过去分词：变稠或凝固；（使某物）变稠或凝固。

examples.en: The sauce congealed quickly after we turned off the heat.
examples.zh: 我们关火后，酱汁很快就凝固了。

examples.en: Cold air congealed the melted wax on the candle.
examples.zh: 冷空气使蜡烛上融化的蜡凝固了。

extraExplanation: “congealed”常用于食物语境（gravy 肉汁、fat 油脂、wax 蜡），带有“不新鲜、油腻、冷掉了”的联想；在写作里也可用于比喻，如“congealed emotions”（凝结的情感）来表达情绪变得僵硬、停滞。

summary.en: Congealedness means the condition of being congealed—thickened or solidified from a liquid, usually by cooling.
summary.zh: Congealedness 指“凝结/凝固的状态”，即液体通常因冷却而变稠或固化。

definition.en: the state or quality of being congealed (turned from a liquid into a thicker, semi-solid, or solid form, often because of cooling)
definition.zh: 凝结（凝固）状态；指液体因冷却等原因变稠、半固化或固化的性质/程度

examples.en: The congealedness of the sauce shows it was left out too long and cooled down.
examples.zh: 酱汁的凝结状态说明它放在外面太久，已经冷却变稠了。

examples.en: In winter, the congealedness of cooking oil can surprise people in an unheated kitchen.
examples.zh: 冬天在不供暖的厨房里，食用油的凝结程度常常会让人意外。

extraExplanation: “congealedness”来自动词 congeal（凝结、凝固），后缀 -ness 用来把形容词/过去分词形式变成名词，表示“……的状态/性质”。在日常英语中，人们更常说 the food congealed / the sauce has congealed，或用名词 congealment（较少见）来表达。

summary.en: A congealer is usually an ingredient or substance that makes a liquid thicken or set; more generally, it can be anything that causes something to congeal.
summary.zh: congealer 通常指让液体变稠或凝固定型的“凝固剂”；更广义也可指任何导致凝结/凝固的因素。

definition.en: a substance or ingredient that makes a liquid thicken or become firm (for example, gelatin used to set a dessert)
definition.zh: 凝固剂；使液体变稠或变成固体的物质/成分（如用来让甜点定型的明胶）

examples.en: Gelatin is a common congealer in many chilled desserts.
examples.zh: 明胶是许多冷藏甜点里常见的凝固剂。

examples.en: The recipe calls for a congealer so the sauce will set properly.
examples.zh: 这个食谱需要加入凝固剂，这样酱汁才能正确凝固定型。

definition.en: someone or something that causes something to congeal (to thicken or solidify)
definition.zh: 使……凝结/凝固的人或事物

examples.en: Cold air can be a congealer, turning water into ice overnight.
examples.zh: 冷空气可以成为“凝固者”，一夜之间把水变成冰。

examples.en: In the fridge, time is the congealer that helps the mixture firm up.
examples.zh: 在冰箱里，时间就是让混合物变硬定型的“凝固者”。

extraExplanation: “congealer”来自动词“congeal”（凝结、凝固）+ 后缀“-er”（表示“做某事的人/物”）。在日常英语里，更常见的说法是“thickener”（增稠剂）或“gelling agent”（凝胶剂/凝固剂）；“congealer”相对少见，但在烹饪或说明性文字中仍可能出现。

summary.en: Congealing means becoming thick or semi-solid (often as something cools), or figuratively becoming fixed and clearly formed.
summary.zh: congealing 表示（液体）变稠/凝结成半固体；也可比喻（想法、计划、情绪等）逐渐定型、变得清晰。

definition.en: becoming thicker or turning from liquid to a semi-solid (for example, fat, sauce, jelly, or blood) as it cools or sits
definition.zh: （液体）逐渐变稠、凝结，变成半固体（如油脂、酱汁、果冻或血液），常因冷却或放置而发生

examples.en: The soup is congealing on the stove because the heat is too low.
examples.zh: 火太小，汤在炉子上开始凝结变稠了。

examples.en: Wipe the pan before the grease starts congealing.
examples.zh: 趁油脂还没凝结，先把锅擦干净。

examples.en: There was congealing blood around the cut.
examples.zh: 伤口周围有正在凝结的血。

definition.en: (figurative) becoming fixed, settled, or clearly formed; coming together into a solid plan or idea
definition.zh: （比喻）逐渐定型、固定下来；（想法/计划）变得清晰并形成体系

examples.en: After a few meetings, the team’s ideas started congealing into a real plan.
examples.zh: 开了几次会后，团队的想法开始凝聚成一个真正的计划。

examples.en: Her vague worries were congealing into a specific fear.
examples.zh: 她模糊的担忧逐渐凝结成一种明确的恐惧。

extraExplanation: “congealing”来自动词 congeal，常用于食物（油脂、肉汁、汤、果冻）等在温度下降后变稠或凝固的过程。
也常用于描写“血液凝结（congealing blood）”，在文学或新闻中往往带有较强的画面感与情绪色彩。
比喻用法很常见：ideas/feelings/plans congeal 表示“逐渐成形、定型”，语气比 form 更强调从模糊到清晰、从松散到稳固的过程。

summary.en: Congealment means the process or result of a liquid becoming thick or solid, or the thick/clotted mass that forms.
summary.zh: Congealment 指液体变稠或凝固的过程/结果，也可指凝结后形成的块状物（凝结物）。

definition.en: the process of becoming thick or solid (or the state of being thickened/solidified), especially when a liquid cools
definition.zh: （尤指液体冷却时）凝结、凝固的过程；或凝结/凝固的状态

examples.en: The congealment of the sauce happens quickly once it cools.
examples.zh: 酱汁一旦冷却，很快就会发生凝结。

examples.en: After a few minutes in the cold air, the congealment of the melted butter was obvious.
examples.zh: 在冷空气中几分钟后，融化的黄油明显开始凝固。

definition.en: a thickened or clotted mass formed by congealing
definition.zh: 凝结物；凝固后形成的块状物（如凝结的脂肪或血块）

examples.en: A congealment of fat floated on the surface of the soup.
examples.zh: 一层凝结的油脂漂在汤面上。

examples.en: The doctor examined the congealment in the wound to check for abnormal clotting.
examples.zh: 医生检查伤口中的凝结物，以确认是否存在异常凝血。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：congeal 来自拉丁语，含“聚在一起、冻结”的意思；-ment 常把动词变成名词，表示“过程/结果”。因此 congealment 常强调“凝结这一过程”或“凝结后的结果（凝结物）”。
用法区分：日常写作里更常用 congealing（凝结过程）或 congealed（已凝结的）来描述状态；congealment 更偏正式、书面或医学/技术语境。

summary.en: “Congeals” means becomes thick or semi-solid (or, figuratively, becomes fixed).
summary.zh: “congeals”表示（液体）变稠/凝固；也可比喻（想法、局势）逐渐定型、僵化。

definition.en: (of a liquid) to become thicker or semi-solid, often as it cools.
definition.zh: （液体）变稠或凝固，常因冷却而发生。

examples.en: The soup congeals if you leave it out too long.
examples.zh: 汤如果在外面放太久会变稠甚至凝固。

examples.en: Fat congeals on top of the stew after it cools.
examples.zh: 炖菜冷却后，油脂会在表面凝结。

definition.en: (figurative) to become fixed, rigid, or less able to change; to form into a settled shape or idea.
definition.zh: （比喻）变得固定、僵化或不再容易改变；（想法/局势）定型。

examples.en: Over time, the plan congeals into a routine.
examples.zh: 随着时间推移，这个计划逐渐定型成一种惯例。

examples.en: Fear congealed into anger during the argument.
examples.zh: 争吵中，恐惧逐渐凝结成愤怒。

definition.en: to cause something (especially a liquid) to thicken or become semi-solid.
definition.zh: 使（尤指液体）变稠或凝固。

examples.en: Cold air congeals the melted butter quickly.
examples.zh: 冷空气会让融化的黄油很快凝固。

extraExplanation: “congeals”是动词“congeal”的第三人称单数（he/she/it congeals）。过去式/过去分词：congealed。
常见搭配：blood congeals（血液凝固/让人毛骨悚然）、fat congeals（油脂凝结）、ideas congeal（想法成形/定型）。
与“coagulate”相比：congeal更口语、范围更广（任何液体变稠/凝固，或比喻“定型”）；coagulate更偏医学/生物语境，常指血液或蛋白质“凝固”。

summary.en: **conged** is a rare form meaning “became thick/solid” (past of *conge*). In modern English, **congealed** is much more common.
summary.zh: **conged** 很少见，意思是“变稠/凝固了”（*conge* 的过去式）。现代英语更常用 **congealed**。

definition.en: (rare) Past tense/past participle of **conge**: to become thick or solid (especially a liquid as it cools), or to make something do this.
definition.zh: （罕见）**conge** 的过去式/过去分词：使（液体）变稠或凝固；（液体）冷却后变稠或凝固。

examples.en: The sauce **conged** as it cooled on the stove.
examples.zh: 酱汁在炉子上冷却时变稠凝固了。

examples.en: Leave the fat overnight until it has **conged** into a firm layer.
examples.zh: 把油脂放一夜，直到它凝固成一层硬硬的脂肪。

definition.en: (rare, literary) Describing something that has thickened or solidified.
definition.zh: （罕见，文学用法）形容“已经变稠/凝固的”。

examples.en: He scraped the **conged** grease from the pan.
examples.zh: 他把锅里已经凝固的油脂刮了下来。

extraExplanation: “conged”在现代英语里非常少见，更常用的是 **congealed**（凝固的/变稠的）或动词 **congeal**（凝固；使凝固）。如果你是在食谱、旧文学或较正式的写作里看到“conged”，通常就是“conge/congeal（凝固）”这个意思。
注意别和法语 **congé**（休假、假期）混淆：英语里偶尔会借用作 **congé**（如 *congé leave*），但那不是“conged”的常见来源。

summary.en: Congee is a rice porridge, common in many Asian cuisines, often eaten for breakfast or as comfort food when sick.
summary.zh: Congee 指米粥（亚洲常见），常作早餐或病中/清淡的暖胃食物。

definition.en: A thick rice porridge made by cooking rice in lots of water until it breaks down; commonly eaten in many Asian cuisines, often for breakfast or when someone is sick.
definition.zh: 粥；（通常指亚洲常见的）米粥，把米用大量水煮到软烂成稠粥，常作早餐或病中食物。

examples.en: I had congee for breakfast with a boiled egg and scallions.
examples.zh: 我早餐吃了粥，配水煮蛋和葱花。

examples.en: When I caught a cold, my mom made ginger congee for me.
examples.zh: 我感冒时，我妈妈给我煮了姜粥。

examples.en: You can top congee with shredded chicken, pickles, or soy sauce.
examples.zh: 你可以在粥上加鸡丝、腌菜或酱油作配料。

extraExplanation: “Congee”在英语里主要指东亚与东南亚常见的“米粥/稀饭”，粤语里常对应“粥”(juk1)，普通话常说“粥”或更具体如“白粥、皮蛋瘦肉粥”。不同地区做法与口感差异很大：有的很稀，有的非常浓稠。
词源上，英语 congee 多被认为来自泰米尔语/马来语等南亚、东南亚语言中的相关词（在殖民贸易时期进入英语），所以它在英文菜单里常用于泛指“亚洲风格的米粥”。
文化用法上，英语里说 congee 往往带有“comfort food（暖胃、疗愈的家常食物）”的感觉，特别是提到生病、宿醉或想吃清淡食物时。

summary.en: “Congeed” is an archaic past form meaning “dismissed/sent away” or “took leave.”
summary.zh: “congeed”是较古旧的过去式，常表示“被解雇/被遣散/被准许退下”或“告辞离开”。

definition.en: past tense/past participle of (archaic) “congee”: to dismiss or discharge someone from service or duty; to send someone away with permission to leave.
definition.zh: （古语）“congee”的过去式/过去分词：解雇、遣散（某人）；准许某人离去、让某人告退。

examples.en: After the ceremony, the servants were congeed for the night.
examples.zh: 仪式结束后，仆人们被准许退下休息。

examples.en: The officer was congeed from duty due to illness.
examples.zh: 那名军官因病被准许离岗。

definition.en: past tense/past participle of (archaic) “congee”: to take one’s leave; to depart politely.
definition.zh: （古语）“congee”的过去式/过去分词：告辞；礼貌地离开。

examples.en: She congeed and left the room without a word.
examples.zh: 她告辞后一句话也没说就离开了房间。

extraExplanation: “congeed”很少见，属于偏古旧/文学用法，来源与法语“congé”（许可、告假、解雇）有关。
注意不要和常见的名词“congee”（米粥）混淆：米粥的“congee”读音和词义都不同，且一般不会写成“congeed”。如果你想表达“凝固”，更常用的是“congealed”（来自 congeal）。

summary.en: Congeeing means “becoming thick or solid,” especially as something cools, or (of blood) “clotting.”
summary.zh: congeeing 指“正在变稠或凝固”（常因冷却），也可指血液“正在凝结成血块”。

definition.en: (present participle of congeal) becoming thicker, more solid, or jelly-like (often as something cools).
definition.zh: （congeal 的现在分词）逐渐变稠、凝固，或变成果冻状（常因冷却）。

examples.en: The sauce is congeeing as it cools, so stir it gently.
examples.zh: 酱汁在冷却时正在变稠凝固，所以轻轻搅拌一下。

examples.en: After a few hours in the fridge, the fat starts congeeing on top of the soup.
examples.zh: 在冰箱里放了几个小时后，脂肪开始在汤面上凝结。

definition.en: (of blood or a liquid in the body) clotting or thickening into a semi-solid mass.
definition.zh: （指血液或体液）凝结、凝固成半固态（形成血块）。

examples.en: The blood was congeeing around the cut.
examples.zh: 血液正在伤口周围凝结。

examples.en: Apply pressure to help stop the bleeding before it starts congeeing.
examples.zh: 在血液开始凝结之前先按压止血。

extraExplanation: “congeeing”来自动词“congeal”（凝固）。它常见于写作或说明文里，强调“正在变稠/正在凝固”的过程。
拼写注意：congeal 去掉 -al 加 -ing 变为 congealing；但实际用法中也会出现 congeeing 这种拼写（较少见），多因读音与拼写类推造成。更常用、更标准的是 congealing。

summary.en: Congee is a thick rice porridge, commonly eaten in many Asian cuisines.
summary.zh: Congee 指（多见于亚洲菜系的）米粥/稀饭。

definition.en: a thick rice porridge (often eaten for breakfast or when someone is sick), usually cooked until the rice breaks down and becomes soft
definition.zh: （常作早餐或生病时吃的）稠稠的米粥/稀饭，米粒煮到软烂化开

examples.en: I had chicken congee for breakfast.
examples.zh: 我早餐吃了鸡肉粥。

examples.en: When she had a cold, her grandmother made her congee with ginger.
examples.zh: 她感冒时，奶奶给她煮了加姜的粥。

examples.en: In this restaurant, congee comes with pickled vegetables and a soft-boiled egg.
examples.zh: 这家餐厅的粥会配腌菜和溏心蛋。

extraExplanation: “congee”常见于英语菜单，指亚洲风格的米粥。美式英语里多读作 /ˈkɑːndʒi/。
词源来自南亚/东南亚地区对“米粥”的称呼（常被认为与泰米尔语 *kanji* 等有关），因此在讲到中餐、港式“粥（juk）”、越南/新加坡等饮食时很常见。
你输入的 **congees** 通常是名词复数：*two congees*（两种/两份粥）。在日常英语里更常说 *two bowls of congee*（两碗粥）或直接用 congee 作不可数名词：*some congee*（一些粥）。

summary.en: **congeeing** means becoming thick/solid (or making something do so), usually as it cools.
summary.zh: **congeeing** 指（通常因冷却而）正在变稠/凝固，或使某物变稠/凝固。

definition.en: (present participle of **congeal**) becoming thick or solid, especially from cooling.
definition.zh: （**congeal** 的现在分词）变稠或凝固，尤指因冷却而凝结。

examples.en: The sauce is congeeing as it cools.
examples.zh: 酱汁在变凉时正在变稠。

examples.en: Fat can start congeeing on the surface of the soup.
examples.zh: 油脂可能会开始在汤面上凝结。

definition.en: making something thicken or solidify.
definition.zh: 使某物变稠或凝固。

examples.en: Cold air is congeeing the oil into a semi-solid layer.
examples.zh: 冷空气正使油凝成半固体的一层。

extraExplanation: 你输入的 **congeing** 通常是拼写错误，更常见的正确拼法是 **congeeing**（来自动词 **congeal**）。
发音上常让人困惑：**congeal** /kənˈdʒiːl/ 的 -eal 变化成 **congeeing** 时写作 **-eeing**，读起来像 “jee-ing”。
常见搭配：**congeeing fat/grease**（凝固的油脂）、**congeeing sauce**（变稠的酱汁）。在写作里也可比喻“气氛/情绪凝结”：*The tension was congeeing in the room.*（紧张气氛在房间里凝聚/加剧）。

summary.en: Congelation means the process of becoming solid (or the solid mass formed), often in technical or medical contexts.
summary.zh: Congelation 指“凝固/冻结的过程”，也可指“凝结物”，多见于技术或医学语境。

definition.en: The process of becoming solid or semi-solid, especially when a liquid thickens or freezes (often used in technical or medical contexts).
definition.zh: （尤指液体）凝固、冻结或变稠的过程（常用于技术或医学语境）。

examples.en: After the temperature dropped, the oil showed signs of congelation.
examples.zh: 气温下降后，油开始出现凝固的迹象。

examples.en: Doctors monitored the blood sample for abnormal congelation.
examples.zh: 医生监测血样是否出现异常凝固。

definition.en: A mass or lump that has formed by congealing; something that has solidified.
definition.zh: 凝结物；由凝固形成的一团（块）固体。

examples.en: A thin congelation formed on the surface of the sauce as it cooled.
examples.zh: 酱汁冷却时，表面形成了一层薄薄的凝结物。

examples.en: He scraped away the congelation of fat from the soup.
examples.zh: 他把汤上凝结的油脂刮掉了。

extraExplanation: “congelation”较正式，日常更常说“freezing”（冻结）或“thickening/setting”（变稠/凝固）。
词源与拉丁语“congelare”（使冻结/凝固）有关；同源词有“congeal”（凝固）。在医学里可与“coagulation”（凝血/凝固）相关，但两者不完全等同：coagulation更强调化学或生理的凝固过程（如血液凝固）。

summary.en: Concerning or causing freezing/congealing; a rare, somewhat old-fashioned word.
summary.zh: （较罕见/略旧）与冻结、凝结有关；或指“使之冻结/凝结”的。

definition.en: causing something (especially a liquid) to congeal or freeze; having a freezing/solidifying effect
definition.zh: 使（尤指液体）凝结或冻结的；具有使之结冰/固化作用的

examples.en: The report mentioned a congested, cold, almost congelative wind coming off the river.
examples.zh: 报告提到河面吹来一阵又冷又闷的风，几乎有种“冻住一切”的凝结感。

examples.en: In older scientific writing, certain salts were described as having a “congelative” effect on solutions.
examples.zh: 在较早的科学写作中，有些盐被描述为对溶液具有“促凝/致冻”的作用。

extraExplanation: “congelative”是较少见的词，来自拉丁语词根 con-（一起）+ gel-（冰、冻结），与 congeal（凝结）、congealed（凝固的）同源。现代英语里更常用的表达通常是 freezing、congealing、solidifying，或在科学语境中用 causing congelation/inducing freezing。
它有时出现在较文学化或较旧的描述中，用来强调“让事物仿佛被冻住/凝住”的感觉，而不一定是字面意义上的结冰。

summary.en: Conge​lifract is a rare literary adjective meaning “cracked or broken by freezing (frost).”
summary.zh: congelifract 是一个罕见的文学形容词，意思是“因冻结/霜冻而开裂或破碎的”。

definition.en: (rare, literary) Broken or cracked by freezing; frost-shattered.
definition.zh: （罕见，文学用语）因冻结而破裂的；被霜冻（冻裂）弄碎的。

examples.en: The hikers crossed a field of congelifract rocks, split by winter ice.
examples.zh: 徒步者穿过一片被冬季冰冻裂开的岩石地带。

examples.en: In the poem, the old wall stands among congelifract stones and cold wind.
examples.zh: 在诗中，古墙伫立在冻裂的石块与寒风之间。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：来自拉丁语 con-（一起）+ gelu（冰、霜）+ fractus（破碎的）。常见于描写冬季自然景观的文学语境，日常英语里更常说 “frost-shattered / frost-cracked”。
用法提醒：它通常修饰“岩石、石块、地面、墙体”等会因结冰膨胀而开裂的事物。

summary.en: Congelifraction is freeze–thaw action that breaks rock or soil.
summary.zh: Congelifraction 指反复冻融导致岩石或土壤破裂的作用。

definition.en: the process in which water freezes and thaws repeatedly, causing materials (especially rock or soil) to crack, split, or break apart
definition.zh: 反复冻融的过程；水结冰又融化，导致材料（尤指岩石或土壤）开裂、分裂或破碎

examples.en: In cold climates, congelifraction can slowly break rocks into smaller pieces.
examples.zh: 在寒冷气候中，冻融作用会慢慢把岩石破碎成更小的碎块。

examples.en: The cracks widened over winter due to repeated congelifraction.
examples.zh: 由于反复冻融，裂缝在冬季变得更宽了。

extraExplanation: 这是一个非常少见、偏学术的词，常见于地质学/地貌学语境。更常用的近义表达是“freeze-thaw weathering（冻融风化）”或“frost wedging（霜楔作用）”。
词源来自拉丁语：congelare（使冻结）+ fractio（破裂/断裂），字面意思接近“因冻结而破裂”。

summary.en: A humorous, nonstandard verb meaning “to congeal/freeze while being churned or disturbed.”
summary.zh: 一个幽默的非标准动词，指“在被搅动/扰乱的同时凝固或冻结”。

definition.en: (Nonstandard; humorous/nonce) To make something partly freeze or congeal while also stirring or disturbing it; to turn into a slushy, churned-up state.
definition.zh: （非标准；幽默/临时造词）使某物一边冻结/凝固、一边被搅动或扰乱；变成被搅得乱七八糟的半凝固（像冰沙、雪泥）状态。

examples.en: By the time we got there, the half-melted ice cream had basically congeliturbated into a gritty slush.
examples.zh: 我们到那儿时，半融化的冰淇淋基本已经“congeliturbate”成一团粗糙的冰沙状了。

examples.en: Don’t keep opening the freezer door—you’ll just congeliturbate the sauce instead of letting it set.
examples.zh: 别老开冷冻室门——那样只会把酱料弄成半凝固又被扰乱的状态，而不是让它顺利凝住。

extraExplanation: “congeliturbate”不是常见英语词，也通常不收录在主流词典里，更像是幽默的拼造词（nonce word）。它看起来由 **congeal/congel-（凝固、冻结）** + **turb-（搅动、浑浊、扰乱）** 之类的词根/联想拼成，用来夸张形容“又冻又被搅乱”的尴尬状态。
如果你是在某本书、游戏、网络梗或特定语境里看到它，欢迎贴出原句；我可以根据上下文给出更贴切的译法与用法建议。

summary.en: Congeliturbation is a rare literary noun meaning a “frozen” kind of confusion or turmoil—disturbance that feels stuck or immobilized.
summary.zh: congeliturbation 是一个罕见的文学名词，指带有“冻结、僵住”感的混乱或动荡：既不安又难以前进。

definition.en: (Rare, literary) A state of confusion or disturbance that feels “frozen” or stuck; turmoil mixed with stiffness, numbness, or immobilization.
definition.zh: （罕见，文学用语）一种带有“冻结/僵住”感觉的混乱或骚动；既动荡又像被卡住、麻木、难以推进的状态。

examples.en: After the sudden blackout, the crowd fell into a kind of congeliturbation—moving, but somehow stuck.
examples.zh: 突然停电后，人群陷入一种“congeliturbation”——在动，却又像卡住了一样。

examples.en: His grief was not loud; it was a quiet congeliturbation that made every decision feel impossible.
examples.zh: 他的悲伤并不张扬；而是一种安静的“congeliturbation”，让每个决定都变得难以做出。

extraExplanation: 这个词非常少见，通常被视为“造词/拼成词”（nonce word / portmanteau），由表示“冻结”的词根（如 congeal / congel-）与表示“骚动、混乱”的 -turbation（如 perturbation）拼合而来。
它常被提到与詹姆斯·乔伊斯（James Joyce）等现代主义文本的语言实验有关；在日常英语里几乎不会用到，更适合在文学分析、创意写作或模仿乔伊斯式语言时使用。

summary.en: **Congenitor** means a parent/ancestor or the original source that something comes from (formal).
summary.zh: **Congenitor** 指“父母/祖先”，也可指“某事物的起源者、源头”（较正式）。

definition.en: (Likely intended: **congenitor**) a parent, ancestor, or the original source of a family line or group.
definition.zh: （你可能想写的是 **congenitor**）父母之一；祖先；（家族/群体的）始祖、起源者。

examples.en: Her grandfather was a **congenitor** of the family’s farming tradition.
examples.zh: 她的祖父是这个家族农耕传统的奠基者（始祖之一）。

examples.en: Scientists sometimes refer to an early species as the **congenitor** of modern animals.
examples.zh: 科学家有时把某种早期物种称为现代动物的“祖先物种”。

definition.en: A person or thing that produces, originates, or gives rise to something (more formal usage).
definition.zh: （更正式用法）产生某事物的人或事物；起源、源头。

examples.en: Many people see fear as the **congenitor** of prejudice.
examples.zh: 许多人认为恐惧是偏见的源头。

examples.en: That small startup was the **congenitor** of an entire new industry.
examples.zh: 那家小型初创公司成了一个全新行业的源头。

extraExplanation: “congenator”不是常见或标准拼写。你可能想查的是 **congenitor**（更常用），意思是“父母/祖先/起源者”。
词源提示：**congenitor** 来自拉丁语 *con-*（共同）+ *gen-*（生、产生），因此带有“生出、产生、起源”的含义。语体偏正式，写作中更常见。

summary.en: A congener is something closely related in the same kind or group (especially in biology or chemistry).
summary.zh: congener 指同类/同属的近缘事物（尤用于生物学或化学语境）。

definition.en: A thing (often an organism or chemical) that belongs to the same group, kind, or genus as another; something closely related in type.
definition.zh: （常指生物或化学物质）同类的事物；同属/同一类群中的成员；近缘物。

examples.en: Whales and dolphins are congeners in the same order of marine mammals.
examples.zh: 鲸和海豚是同一类海洋哺乳动物中的近缘成员。

examples.en: This congener has a similar structure but behaves differently in the experiment.
examples.zh: 这种同系物结构相似，但在实验中的表现不同。

definition.en: Belonging to the same kind, group, or genus; closely related.
definition.zh: 同类的；同属的；近缘的。

examples.en: They compared two congener species to see how they adapted to different climates.
examples.zh: 他们比较了两个同属物种，看看它们如何适应不同气候。

examples.en: The lab tested several congener compounds with only small changes in their molecules.
examples.zh: 实验室测试了几种同系化合物，它们的分子只略有差异。

extraExplanation: 在生物学里，congener常指“同属（同一genus）”的物种，例如同属的两种鸟。
在化学里，congener常指“同系物/同类化合物”，即结构很相似、只在某些部分（如碳链长度、取代基）不同的一组化合物。
词源：来自拉丁语 con-（共同）+ genus（种类/属）。因此它的核心意思就是“同一类/同一家族”。
近义表达（语境不同）：related species（相关物种）、counterpart（对应物）、member of the same genus（同属成员）。其中congener更偏学术/技术用语。

summary.en: Congeneracy means a close relationship of being of the same kind—often, belonging to the same genus in biology.
summary.zh: Congeneracy 指“同类/同属的关系”，常用于生物学中表示“属于同一属”的亲缘或分类关系。

definition.en: the state of being closely related, especially belonging to the same genus (in biology) or the same general kind
definition.zh: 同属关系；同类性（尤指生物分类中属于同一属，或更广义上的同一类/相近类别）

examples.en: Researchers tested the congeneracy of several beetle species based on DNA evidence.
examples.zh: 研究人员根据 DNA 证据检验了几种甲虫物种的同属关系。

examples.en: Their debate focused on whether these plants show true congeneracy or only superficial similarity.
examples.zh: 他们的讨论集中在这些植物是否体现真正的同属关系，还是仅仅外表相似。

extraExplanation: “congeneracy”较少见，学术写作中更常用形容词/名词形式如“congeneric (species)”（同属的物种）或直接说“congeners”（同属物种）。
词根来源：con-（共同）+ genus（属/种类）。在生物分类语境中，“genus”指“属”，因此该词常用于讨论分类学与亲缘关系。

summary.en: Congeneric means “of the same genus” (biology) or more generally “of the same kind; closely similar,” and it’s mainly used in formal/academic contexts.
summary.zh: congeneric 意为“同属的”（生物学）或更广义的“同类的、很相似的”，多用于正式/学术语境。

definition.en: Belonging to the same genus; closely related in biological classification.
definition.zh: （生物分类）同属的；属于同一属、亲缘关系很近的。

examples.en: Lions and tigers are congeneric species because they belong to the genus Panthera.
examples.zh: 狮子和老虎是同属物种，因为它们都属于豹属（Panthera）。

examples.en: The paper compared congeneric plants to see how they adapted to different climates.
examples.zh: 这篇论文比较了同属植物，看看它们如何适应不同气候。

definition.en: Of the same kind or category; very similar in nature.
definition.zh: 同类的；性质或类别非常相近的。

examples.en: The author groups congeneric themes—loss and renewal—throughout the novel.
examples.zh: 作者在小说中贯穿了同类主题——失去与重生。

examples.en: Researchers tested congeneric materials with similar chemical structures.
examples.zh: 研究人员测试了同类材料，它们的化学结构相似。

extraExplanation: “congeneric”常见于学术写作，尤其是生物学/生态学论文里，比日常口语更正式。
词源：con-（一起/共同）+ generic（同类的/属的）。在分类学里genus=“属”，所以它常被用来强调“同属”。
近义表达（按语境）：taxonomic语境可用“in the same genus / within the same genus”；泛指“同类”时可用“similar / of the same type”。

summary.en: Congeneric means “belonging to the same genus” (most common), and more loosely “of the same kind.”
summary.zh: congeneric 主要指“同属的（同一属的）”，也可较宽泛地指“同类的”。

definition.en: Belonging to the same genus; closely related within a biological classification.
definition.zh: （生物分类）同属的；属于同一属的；同属近缘的。

examples.en: Lions and tigers are congeneric species because they belong to the genus Panthera.
examples.zh: 狮子和老虎是同属物种，因为它们都属于豹属（Panthera）。

examples.en: Researchers compared congeneric plants to see how traits change across species in the same genus.
examples.zh: 研究人员比较了同属植物，以了解同一属内不同物种的性状如何变化。

definition.en: Very similar in kind or category; sharing the same broad type (less common).
definition.zh: （较少见）同类的；同种类的；性质相近的。

examples.en: The study looked at congeneric forms of storytelling across different cultures.
examples.zh: 这项研究考察了不同文化中同类的叙事形式。

examples.en: We need congeneric examples to make a fair comparison.
examples.zh: 我们需要同类的例子，才能做出公平的比较。

extraExplanation: “congenerical”更常见被视为“congeneric”的少见变体或拼写错误；在学术写作（尤其是生物学/分类学）中通常用“congeneric”。
词源提示：con-（共同）+ generic（同类/属的），常出现在分类学表达中，如“congeneric species（同属物种）”。

summary.en: “Congenerous” means “of the same kind or class; similar.”
summary.zh: “Congenerous”意为“同类的、同种的；相似的”。

definition.en: (of things or people) belonging to the same kind, class, or group; similar in nature.
definition.zh: （事物或人）同类的；同种的；性质相近的。

examples.en: Lions and tigers are congenerous animals because they belong to the same cat family.
examples.zh: 狮子和老虎是同类动物，因为它们同属猫科。

examples.en: She compared two congenerous traditions from different regions to see what they shared.
examples.zh: 她比较了来自不同地区的两种同类传统，看看它们有哪些共同点。

extraExplanation: 这个词较正式、偏学术写作，常见于生物学（同属/同科的生物）、分类学、或讨论“同一类别”的观念比较。
词源上与拉丁语词根“gen-（出生、种类）”有关：con- 表示“共同”，-gener- 表示“种类/产生”，合起来就是“同一种类的”。

summary.en: Congenerousness means the quality of being of the same kind or closely related in nature or origin.
summary.zh: Congenerousness 指“同类性”，即在种类、性质或来源上同种或密切相关的特质。

definition.en: the quality of being congenerous; similarity in kind, nature, or origin
definition.zh: 同类性；同种/同源的性质；（在种类、性质或来源上的）相似性

examples.en: The congenerousness of the two traditions makes the comparison clearer.
examples.zh: 这两种传统的同类性让比较更清晰。

examples.en: Scientists discussed the congenerousness of these compounds before naming them.
examples.zh: 科学家在给这些化合物命名之前讨论了它们的同类性。

extraExplanation: “Congenerousness”来自形容词 congenerous（同类的、同种的），核心意思是“属于同一类/同一来源，因此相似”。在现代英语里更常见的表达是 similarity（相似性）、relatedness（关联性）或 the fact that they are congeneric（它们同属一类/同一属）。
词根提示：con- 表示“共同”，-gen- 与 “产生/种类”（如 generate, genus）有关，因此 congenerous 强调“同源同类”。

summary.en: “Congeners” is the plural of “congener”: closely related things—especially related chemical compounds—or members of the same kind/group.
summary.zh: “congeners”是“congener”的复数：指彼此近缘的事物，尤指化学中的同系物；也可指同类/同族的成员。

definition.en: A thing (or substance) that is closely related to another; in chemistry, a related compound in the same family or series (often with similar structure and properties).
definition.zh: 同类物；近缘物（尤指化学中同系物/同族化合物，结构与性质相近）。

examples.en: Chemists measured several congeners of the same pesticide to see which one was most toxic.
examples.zh: 化学家测量了同一种农药的几个同系物，以比较哪一种毒性最大。

examples.en: PCBs include many congeners that differ slightly in structure but can have very different health effects.
examples.zh: 多氯联苯（PCB）包含许多同系物，它们结构差异很小，但对健康的影响可能差别很大。

definition.en: A person, animal, or plant that belongs to the same kind or group; a close relative or counterpart.
definition.zh: 同类的人/动物/植物；近亲；同族成员。

examples.en: Humans and their primate congeners share many behaviors.
examples.zh: 人类与其灵长类同族成员共享许多行为特征。

examples.en: In the novel, the hero feels like an outsider among his wealthy congeners.
examples.zh: 在小说中，主人公在富裕的同类人群中感到格格不入。

extraExplanation: “congener”来自拉丁语：con-（共同）+ genus（种类、族群），字面意思是“同一种类的”。
在环境科学/毒理学里常说“PCB congeners（多氯联苯同系物）”“dioxin congeners（二噁英同系物）”，强调同一类化学物质中不同“成员”的细微结构差异。

summary.en: “Congenetic” means present at birth or inborn (often used like “congenital,” but less common).
summary.zh: congenetic 意为“先天的/与生俱来的”（常与 congenital 同义，但更少见）。

definition.en: (Medical) present at birth; existing from the time of birth (often due to genes or fetal development).
definition.zh: （医学）先天的；出生时就存在的（常与基因或胎儿发育有关）。

examples.en: The doctor said the heart problem was congenetic, not caused by the accident.
examples.zh: 医生说这个心脏问题是先天的，不是事故造成的。

examples.en: Some congenetic conditions can be treated early if they are found in newborn screening.
examples.zh: 一些先天疾病如果在新生儿筛查中发现，可以尽早治疗。

definition.en: (General) inborn; naturally belonging to a person or thing from the start.
definition.zh: （一般）与生俱来的；从一开始就自然具备的。

examples.en: She had a congenetic sense of rhythm and learned music quickly.
examples.zh: 她有与生俱来的节奏感，学音乐很快。

extraExplanation: “congenetic”在现代英语里不如“congenital”常见。医学语境中更常写congenital（先天的）。
注意区分：congenital强调“出生时就有”（可能由遗传或孕期环境导致）；genetic强调“由基因决定/可遗传”。有些疾病是congenital但不一定是genetic。

summary.en: Convivial and easy to get along with, or suitable and compatible with someone’s needs or preferences.
summary.zh: 既可指人“友善好相处”，也可指环境或条件“适合、合拍、相容”。

definition.en: Pleasant, friendly, and easy to get along with; (of a person) having a warm, likable manner.
definition.zh: 令人愉快、友善、好相处的；（指人）和蔼可亲、讨人喜欢的。

examples.en: Our new neighbor is very congenial, so we often chat in the hallway.
examples.zh: 我们的新邻居很友善好相处，所以我们经常在走廊里聊天。

examples.en: She has a congenial personality that makes people feel comfortable.
examples.zh: 她的性格很随和亲切，让人觉得很放松。

definition.en: Suitable or compatible; (of conditions, ideas, or environments) matching what someone likes or needs.
definition.zh: 适合的；相容的；（指环境、条件或想法）与某人的喜好或需求相契合的。

examples.en: The team worked best in a congenial environment where everyone shared ideas freely.
examples.zh: 在一个氛围融洽、大家能自由分享想法的环境里，团队工作效率最高。

examples.en: He chose a job with hours congenial to family life.
examples.zh: 他选择了一份工作时间更适合家庭生活的工作。

extraExplanation: “congenial”常见搭配：congenial person（合得来的人）、congenial atmosphere/environment（融洽的氛围/环境）、congenial company（投缘的伙伴/令人愉快的陪伴）。
词源提示：来自拉丁语词根 con-（一起）+ genus（种类），原意接近“同类/合得来”，所以既可形容“人很友善”，也可形容“环境/条件很合适”。
使用区别小贴士：congenial 更偏“气质/氛围上让人舒服、合拍”；friendly 更直白地表示“友好”。

summary.en: “Congenialities” means pleasant, friendly qualities or polite social niceties that make interactions comfortable.
summary.zh: “congenialities”指令人愉快、友善的特质，或社交中的礼貌寒暄与客套，使相处更舒服。

definition.en: pleasant, friendly qualities or behaviors that make someone enjoyable to be with; friendliness (plural form of “congeniality”).
definition.zh: 令人愉快、友善的特质或举止，使人相处起来舒服；和气、亲切（“congeniality”的复数）。

examples.en: Her congenialities made new employees feel welcome on their first day.
examples.zh: 她亲切友善的特质让新员工第一天就感到受欢迎。

examples.en: At the dinner, he offered small congenialities—warm smiles and kind words—to ease the tension.
examples.zh: 在晚宴上，他用一些友善的小举动——温暖的微笑和好听的话——来缓和紧张气氛。

definition.en: friendly social exchanges or polite gestures used to create a comfortable atmosphere (often: “exchange congenialities”).
definition.zh: （社交中）友好的寒暄、客套话或礼貌性的友善举动（常见搭配：exchange congenialities）。

examples.en: They exchanged congenialities before getting down to business.
examples.zh: 他们先寒暄了几句，然后才开始谈正事。

examples.en: A few congenialities helped the two sides start the meeting on a positive note.
examples.zh: 几句友好的客套话让双方以积极的氛围开始会议。

extraExplanation: “congenialities”来自形容词 congenial（合得来、令人愉快的）。注意它和 genial（和蔼的、亲切的）很像：genial 更强调“性格温暖”，congenial 更强调“相处合拍/环境适合”。
常见表达：exchange congenialities（互致寒暄/客套）、social congenialities（社交礼数、寒暄）。在正式写作里更常见单数 congeniality；复数 congenialities 常用来强调“多种友善举动/寒暄”。

summary.en: Congeniality means friendly harmony—an easy, pleasant way of getting along with others.
summary.zh: Congeniality 指“融洽、合得来”的友好和谐氛围或特质。

definition.en: A pleasant, friendly feeling or quality that makes people get along well; the state of being congenial.
definition.zh: 融洽；意气相投；让人相处愉快的友善氛围或品质。

examples.en: There was an easy congeniality in the team, so meetings stayed calm and productive.
examples.zh: 团队里有一种轻松的融洽氛围，所以会议一直很平和、高效。

examples.en: Her congeniality made newcomers feel welcome right away.
examples.zh: 她的亲和与友善让新人立刻感到被欢迎。

extraExplanation: “congeniality”来自形容词“congenial”（合得来、令人愉快的），词根含有“gen”（出生、天性）相关的含义，带有“天性相合、气质契合”的感觉。
在日常英语里，人们更常用“congenial”（adj.）或短语“get along well / good chemistry”来表达；“congeniality”较偏正式，常用于描述气氛、团队关系或社交场合的友好度。

summary.en: Conventional but uncommon verb meaning “to make something more friendly or compatible.”
summary.zh: 较少见的动词，意思是“使更融洽/更合得来”。

definition.en: to make (a person, situation, or relationship) more pleasant, friendly, or compatible
definition.zh: 使（人、情境或关系）更融洽、更合得来、更令人愉快

examples.en: The manager tried to congenialize the workplace by encouraging open communication.
examples.zh: 经理试图通过鼓励坦诚沟通来让工作环境更融洽。

examples.en: A shared hobby can congenialize a group of strangers quickly.
examples.zh: 共同的爱好能很快让一群陌生人变得更合得来。

extraExplanation: “congenialize”在现代英语中比较少见，更常用的是“make … more congenial / create a friendly atmosphere / smooth things over”等表达。
词根提示：congenial（合得来的、融洽的）→ congenialize（使变得融洽）。拼写中含有“gen”（同类/出生/种类的含义），帮助理解“气质相投、相合”。
近义表达（更常见）：to warm things up（让气氛热起来），to foster rapport（促进融洽关系），to build camaraderie（建立情谊）。

summary.en: “Congenially” means “in a friendly, pleasant way,” and sometimes “in a way that suits someone well.”
summary.zh: “congenially”主要表示“亲切友好地、愉快地”，也可表示“很合某人心意/很适合地”。

definition.en: In a friendly, pleasant, and agreeable way; warmly.
definition.zh: 以友好、愉快、合得来的方式；亲切地。

examples.en: She greeted the new coworkers congenially and introduced herself.
examples.zh: 她很亲切地向新同事打招呼，并做了自我介绍。

examples.en: They chatted congenially over coffee after the meeting.
examples.zh: 会议结束后，他们在咖啡时间愉快地聊天。

definition.en: In a way that suits someone’s tastes or mood; pleasantly (often used with “to”).
definition.zh: 以符合某人的喜好或心情的方式；令人愉快地（常与“to”连用）。

examples.en: The relaxed pace of the trip suited her congenially.
examples.zh: 旅行的慢节奏很合她的心意。

examples.en: The calm environment was congenial to quiet study.
examples.zh: 安静的环境很适合安静学习。（对应形容词 congenial 的常见搭配）

extraExplanation: “congenially”来自形容词“congenial”（合得来/令人愉快的）+ 副词后缀“-ly”。它既可以描述人的态度（友善地），也可以描述环境或条件“很合适/很对胃口”。
常见近义词语感区别：friendly（直接=友好）、warmly（更强调热情/温暖）、cordially（更正式、礼貌上的热情）。

summary.en: Congenialness means friendliness and pleasantness, or the quality of being compatible and well-suited.
summary.zh: congenialness 指亲切友善、令人愉快，也可指相合、合拍、适合的特质。

definition.en: The quality of being friendly, pleasant, and easy to get along with; warmth in personality or atmosphere.
definition.zh: （性格或氛围的）亲切、友善、令人愉快；让人容易相处的特质。

examples.en: Her congenialness made new coworkers feel welcome on the first day.
examples.zh: 她的亲切友善让新同事第一天就感到被欢迎。

examples.en: The small café had a quiet congenialness that encouraged people to stay and talk.
examples.zh: 那家小咖啡馆有种安静而温暖的氛围，让人愿意留下来聊天。

definition.en: The quality of being compatible or well-suited to someone’s tastes, needs, or situation.
definition.zh: （与某人喜好、需求或情境）相合、合拍、适合的特质。

examples.en: He chose the job for its congenialness with his long-term goals.
examples.zh: 他选择这份工作，是因为它与他的长期目标很契合。

examples.en: They valued the congenialness of the neighborhood—quiet streets and helpful neighbors.
examples.zh: 他们看重这个社区的宜居与合拍——街道安静、邻居乐于帮忙。

extraExplanation: “congenialness”来自形容词“congenial”（合意的、友善的），词根含义与“同类/同伴（con-）+ 天性/气质（genial，源自拉丁语）”有关，所以既可以指“人很和气”，也可以指“事物很合拍、很适合”。
用法提示：更常见的表达是“congeniality”。“congenialness”可以用，但更偏口语或强调“这种特质本身”。

summary.en: “Congenital” means present from birth; it can also mean inborn as part of someone’s nature.
summary.zh: “congenital”表示“先天的、出生时就有的”，也可指“天生的性格/特质”。

definition.en: Present from birth (especially a medical condition).
definition.zh: 先天的；出生时就有的（尤指医学状况）。

examples.en: She has a congenital heart defect.
examples.zh: 她有先天性心脏缺陷。

examples.en: The doctor explained that the condition is congenital, not caused by anything the parents did.
examples.zh: 医生解释说这种情况是先天的，并不是父母做了什么导致的。

definition.en: Natural to someone’s character; inborn.
definition.zh: 天生的；与生俱来的（性格或能力）。

examples.en: He’s a congenital optimist who always expects things to work out.
examples.zh: 他是个天生的乐观主义者，总觉得事情会顺利。

examples.en: Her congenital curiosity made her ask a lot of questions in class.
examples.zh: 她与生俱来的好奇心让她在课堂上问了很多问题。

extraExplanation: “Congenital”常用于医学语境，表示“出生时就存在”。注意它不等于“genetic（遗传的）”：先天（congenital）可以由遗传因素造成，也可能与孕期环境有关；而遗传（genetic）强调来自基因。
常见搭配：congenital heart defect（先天性心脏缺陷）、congenital disease/disorder（先天性疾病/障碍）、congenital malformation（先天畸形）。
词源提示：con-（一起）+ genitus（出生的），核心含义就是“与出生同时存在”。

summary.en: “Congenitally” means “from birth; in a way someone is born with,” often used in medical or formal contexts.
summary.zh: “congenitally”表示“先天性地、从出生起就有地”，多用于医学或正式语境。

definition.en: In a way that is present from birth; because of a condition someone was born with (often used in medical contexts).
definition.zh: 先天性地；由于出生时就存在的状况（常用于医学语境）。

examples.en: She is congenitally deaf, so she uses sign language.
examples.zh: 她先天性失聪，所以她使用手语。

examples.en: The baby was congenitally blind due to a genetic condition.
examples.zh: 由于遗传疾病，这个婴儿先天性失明。

examples.en: Some heart defects are congenitally present and need early treatment.
examples.zh: 有些心脏缺陷是先天存在的，需要及早治疗。

extraExplanation: “congenitally”通常修饰形容词或过去分词，如 congenitally blind/deaf（先天性失明/失聪）、congenitally missing（先天缺失）。
词根提示：gen 表示“出生/产生”（同源于 generate），con- 有“一起/共同”的意思；整体含义可理解为“与出生一起带来的”。
注意语气与场合：该词多用于正式、医学或科普写作；日常口语里常改说 “born with … / from birth（天生……/从出生起）”。

summary.en: Congenitalness means the state of being congenital—present from birth.
summary.zh: Congenitalness 指“先天性”，即出生时就存在的状态。

definition.en: the quality or state of being congenital (present from birth, often because of genes or conditions during pregnancy)
definition.zh: 先天性；天生就有的状态（出生时就存在，常与遗传或孕期因素有关）

examples.en: Doctors discussed the congenitalness of the heart defect and how it might affect treatment.
examples.zh: 医生讨论了这种心脏缺陷的先天性，以及它可能如何影响治疗方案。

examples.en: Researchers studied the congenitalness of the condition to understand whether it appears at birth or develops later.
examples.zh: 研究人员研究了该疾病的先天性，以判断它是出生时就存在还是后来才发展出来。

extraExplanation: “congenitalness”在现代英语中很少见，听起来偏临时造词；更常用的是“congenitality”（先天性）或直接说“the congenital nature of … / the fact that … is congenital”。
“congenital”多用于医学语境，指“出生时就有”；它不一定等于“遗传的（hereditary）”。例如某些先天缺陷可能与孕期感染、环境因素有关，而不一定来自父母遗传。

summary.en: “Congenital” means “present from birth,” and it can also describe a natural, inborn trait.
summary.zh: “congenital”表示“先天的、出生时就有的”，也可引申为“天生的性格/特质”。

definition.en: born with a particular condition; present from birth (often used in medicine).
definition.zh: 先天的；出生时就有的（常用于医学）。

examples.en: The baby was diagnosed with a congenital heart defect.
examples.zh: 婴儿被诊断为先天性心脏缺陷。

examples.en: Congenital hearing loss can sometimes be treated early.
examples.zh: 先天性听力损失有时可以尽早治疗。

definition.en: natural and long-lasting; seeming to be part of someone’s character from the beginning.
definition.zh: 与生俱来的；天生的（形容性格或习惯等）。

examples.en: He is a congenital optimist who always expects the best.
examples.zh: 他是个天生的乐观主义者，总是期待最好的结果。

extraExplanation: “congenite”在英语里非常少见，日常和学术写作中几乎都不用。多数情况下这是把“congenital（先天的）”拼错了。
“congenital”强调“出生时就存在”，不一定表示“遗传（genetic）”。例如某些先天缺陷可能与孕期环境有关，而不是基因直接造成。
常见搭配：congenital disease/defect/condition（先天性疾病/缺陷/状况）、congenital heart defect（先天性心脏缺陷）。

summary.en: Congeon is a rare word meaning a clotted mass (especially of blood), or (rarely) to congeal.
summary.zh: congeon 是个很少用的词，指（尤指血液的）凝结块/血块；很少也可作动词表示“凝结”。

definition.en: (Rare/old-fashioned) A thick, clotted mass formed when a liquid (especially blood) congeals.
definition.zh: （罕见/旧用法）液体（尤指血液）凝结后形成的块状物；血块。

examples.en: The wound was covered with a dark congeon of dried blood.
examples.zh: 伤口上覆着一层深色的凝结血块。

examples.en: The doctor removed a small congeon from the cut.
examples.zh: 医生从伤口里取出了一小块凝结物。

definition.en: (Very rare) To congeal; to become thick or solid.
definition.zh: （非常罕见）凝结；变稠或变硬。

examples.en: As the sauce cooled, it began to congeon.
examples.zh: 酱汁冷却后开始凝结变稠。

extraExplanation:
“congeon”在现代英语中非常少见，更常见的相关词是：
- congeal（v.）“凝结”
- congestion（n.）“拥堵；（鼻）充血”
很多学习者看到“congeon”其实是想写 congeal 或 congestion。

summary.en: Conger is a large sea eel (conger eel).
summary.zh: conger 指一种大型海鳗（conger eel）。

definition.en: a large sea eel (a type of eel) found in the Atlantic and nearby seas; also called a conger eel
definition.zh: 海鳗；康吉鳗（生活在大西洋等海域的一种大型海鳗）

examples.en: Fishermen pulled a conger from the net and measured its length.
examples.zh: 渔民从网里拉出一条海鳗，并测量它的长度。

examples.en: Conger eels often hide in rocks and feed at night.
examples.zh: 海鳗常躲在岩石缝里，并在夜间觅食。

extraExplanation: “Conger”主要指“conger eel（海鳗）”。在英国、爱尔兰、西班牙和葡萄牙等沿海地区，它也会出现在海鲜料理中。
不要把 conger 和动词 congregate（聚集）混淆：它们拼写相近，但意思完全不同。

summary.en: Conger means a large sea eel, especially the conger eel.
summary.zh: conger 指大型海鳗，尤其是“康吉鳗/海鳗（conger eel）”。

definition.en: a large eel (the conger eel) that lives in the sea; often used as food in some coastal cuisines
definition.zh: 海鳗（康吉鳗）：一种生活在海里的大型鳗鱼；在一些沿海地区也会被当作食物

examples.en: A conger can grow very large and lives in rocky areas along the coast.
examples.zh: 海鳗可能长得很大，常生活在沿海的岩石地带。

examples.en: The fisherman pulled a conger from the net and warned everyone about its strong bite.
examples.zh: 渔夫从网里拉出一条海鳗，并提醒大家它咬合力很强。

examples.en: In some places, conger eel is cooked in stews or grilled.
examples.zh: 在一些地方，海鳗会被用来炖煮或烧烤。

extraExplanation: “Conger”通常指“conger eel（海鳗/康吉鳗）”。在日常英语里，人们更常说完整的“conger eel”，单独说“conger”更偏向渔业、海洋生物或菜单语境。
词源来自拉丁语“conger”（一种鳗鱼），后来进入法语并被英语借用。
注意不要和“conga”（康加鼓/康加舞）混淆：拼写和发音相近，但意思完全不同。

summary.en: Congeree means congee: a soft rice porridge.
summary.zh: Congeree 指 congee：稀饭／米粥。

definition.en: (Variant spelling of “congee”) a soft rice porridge (rice cooked with lots of water until it becomes thick and creamy), common in many Asian cuisines.
definition.zh: （“congee”的拼写变体）稀饭／粥：把米加大量水煮到软烂浓稠的一种米粥，在许多亚洲饮食中很常见。

examples.en: When I’m sick, I like to eat congeree with ginger and a little salt.
examples.zh: 我生病时喜欢吃加姜和一点盐的粥（congeree）。

examples.en: She made chicken congeree for breakfast.
examples.zh: 她早餐做了鸡肉粥（congeree）。

extraExplanation: “Congeree”在英语里不如更常见的拼写“congee”普遍；你在菜单、旧食谱或地区性写法中可能会看到它。
“Congee/congeree”来自南亚语言（常被认为与泰米尔语等词源有关），后来进入英语，用来指这种“米粥/稀饭”这一类食物。

summary.en: Congeries means a mixed collection or heap of different things gathered together.
summary.zh: Congeries 指“杂集、混杂的一堆”，常用于较正式的表达。

definition.en: A collection or group of different things gathered together, often in a mixed or somewhat messy way.
definition.zh: 杂集；混杂的一堆（不同事物聚在一起，常带有“杂乱、拼凑”的感觉）。

examples.en: The museum exhibit was a congeries of photos, letters, and everyday objects from the war.
examples.zh: 那个博物馆展览是一堆战争时期的照片、信件和日常物品的杂集。

examples.en: Her desk had become a congeries of notebooks, receipts, and coffee cups.
examples.zh: 她的桌子变成了笔记本、收据和咖啡杯混在一起的一堆。

extraExplanation: “congeries”在正式写作中更常见，语气比“collection”更文学、更强调“杂乱地聚在一起”。
词源来自拉丁语 congerere（把东西堆在一起）。在学术或文学语境里，可用来形容“材料、观点、细节”等拼成的一团。
用法提示：它常搭配 of（a congeries of ...）。在现代英语中属于较少见但很有表现力的词。

summary.en: Congeries means a piled-up collection or cluster of various things, often used in formal writing.
summary.zh: Congeries 指不同事物堆在一起的集合/一堆，偏正式书面用法。

definition.en: A collection or mass of different things gathered together; a cluster.
definition.zh: （不同事物）聚集在一起的一团/一堆；集合体；簇。

examples.en: On her desk sat a congeries of papers, books, and coffee cups.
examples.zh: 她的桌上堆着一堆纸张、书和咖啡杯。

examples.en: The museum displayed a congeries of artifacts from several ancient cultures.
examples.zh: 博物馆展出了一批来自多个古代文明的文物集合。

examples.en: The city is a congeries of old neighborhoods and new skyscrapers.
examples.zh: 这座城市是老街区与新摩天楼交织而成的集合体。

extraExplanation: 这是一个较正式、偏书面（学术/文学）用词，日常英语更常用 collection、mixture、heap、cluster、assortment 等。
词源来自拉丁语 congeries，来自动词 congerere（把……堆在一起）。在写作中常用来强调“杂而多、堆叠在一起”的感觉，而不一定是整齐分类的集合。

summary.en: “Congers” means conger eels (plural).
summary.zh: “Congers” 指海鳗（conger eel）的复数。

definition.en: Plural of conger: large sea eels (conger eels).
definition.zh: conger 的复数：海鳗（康吉鳗），一种体型较大的海洋鳗鱼。

examples.en: Congers hide in rocks and shipwrecks during the day.
examples.zh: 海鳗白天会躲在岩石和沉船里。

examples.en: The fisherman reported catching two large cong​ers offshore.
examples.zh: 那位渔民说他在近海钓到了两条大海鳗。

extraExplanation: “conger / cong​er eel”常见于英国和欧洲沿海语境（如渔业、海洋生物）。在菜谱里也会出现（例如烤海鳗、炖海鳗），但与淡水的“eel（鳗鱼）”不是同一种。
拼写上以 -ers 结尾表示复数：one conger, two cong​ers。大写 “Congers” 也可能是姓氏或地名的一部分，但作为词汇学习时通常指这种海鳗的复数。

summary.en: “Congers” usually means conger eels (plural): large sea eels.
summary.zh: “congers”通常指海鳗（复数）：一种大型海水鳗鱼。

definition.en: (plural) large sea eels (conger eels), often used as food.
definition.zh: （复数）海鳗（康吉鳗），一种大型海水鳗鱼，常被用作食物。

examples.en: Congers can grow very large and live in rocky coastal waters.
examples.zh: 海鳗可能长得很大，常栖息在多岩的近海水域。

examples.en: The fisherman sold congers at the market early in the morning.
examples.zh: 渔夫一大早就在市场上卖海鳗。

definition.en: (third-person singular, rare) to gather or mass together into a group.
definition.zh: （第三人称单数，较少见）聚集；使成群。

examples.en: Over time, the small groups congers into a larger community.
examples.zh: 随着时间推移，这些小团体聚成了更大的社群。

extraExplanation: “congers”最常见是名词复数，来自“conger eel（海鳗/康吉鳗）”。在英式菜单或渔业语境里更常见。
注意不要和发音/拼写相近的“conjures（变出；召唤）”混淆：conger（海鳗）是名词；conjure 是动词。

summary.en: Congerville is a place name in Illinois, USA.
summary.zh: Congerville 是美国伊利诺伊州的一个地名。

definition.en: a small community (place name) in Illinois, USA; used as a proper noun
definition.zh: （专有名词）美国伊利诺伊州的一个小社区/地名

examples.en: Congerville is a quiet place in central Illinois.
examples.zh: Congerville 是伊利诺伊州中部一个安静的地方。

examples.en: She grew up near Congerville before moving to Chicago.
examples.zh: 她在 Congerville 附近长大，后来搬到了芝加哥。

synonyms: (no direct synonyms; it is a proper place name)
extraExplanation: “Congerville”是美国地名，常见于地址、地图、新闻或个人经历叙述中。它通常指伊利诺伊州伍德福德县（Woodford County）一带的一个小型社区（未必是独立建制城市）。
发音上可拆成“Conger + ville”。其中“-ville”源自法语，常见于美国地名，表示“城镇/村落”（类似中文的“某某镇/村”）。

summary.en: “Congery” means a mixed collection or group of things, often implying clutter or a messy mix.
summary.zh: “Congery”指混杂的一堆/一群东西，常带有杂乱、堆放的感觉。

definition.en: a collection or group of different things (often used to suggest the group is mixed, crowded, or not very well organized)
definition.zh: 一堆；一群；杂糅在一起的集合（常暗示混杂、拥挤或不太整齐）

examples.en: The garage was filled with a congery of old tools, boxes, and broken furniture.
examples.zh: 车库里堆满了各种旧工具、箱子和坏掉的家具。

examples.en: On the table lay a congery of papers from different projects.
examples.zh: 桌上摊着一堆来自不同项目的文件。

extraExplanation: 这个词比较正式、偏书面，在现代日常口语中不算常见；有时带一点“杂乱拼凑”的语气。
词源上与“gather/collect（聚集、收集）”有关，来自拉丁语词根 con-（一起）+ greg-（群、集合）。

summary.en: “Conges” is usually the plural of “congé,” meaning official leave from work or a formal dismissal; it can also mean a jelly-like set dish in cooking (less common).
summary.zh: conges 通常是 congé 的复数，指准假/休假或正式解雇；在烹饪中也可指冻状冷盘或凝结的胶冻层（较少见）。

definition.en: (often plural) official leave from work; permission to be absent, or a formal dismissal.
definition.zh: （常用复数）准假；（正式）离职/被解雇的通知。

examples.en: She is on sick congé this week.
examples.zh: 她这周在休病假。

examples.en: After the argument, he was given his congé.
examples.zh: 争吵之后，他被正式解雇了。

definition.en: to dismiss someone formally; to send away or release from duty.
definition.zh: （正式）解雇；打发走；解除职务。

examples.en: The company congéed several employees during the downturn.
examples.zh: 在经济不景气时，公司正式解雇了几名员工。

definition.en: (cooking, less common) a molded cold dish (similar to jelly/aspic), or the jelly/fat layer that sets on top of broth.
definition.zh: （烹饪，较少见）冻状冷盘；（汤上）凝结的胶冻/油脂层。

examples.en: The broth cooled and a thin congé formed on the surface.
examples.zh: 汤放凉后，表面凝出一层薄薄的胶冻/油脂。

extraExplanation: “conges”多半是“congé”的复数写法；在法语里常写作“congés”，表示“休假/假期”，如“congés payés”（带薪休假）。
注意不要和“congee”（米粥）混淆：congee 指亚洲常见的米粥，拼写和发音都不同。
这个词在现代日常英语中偏正式、也较少见；更常用的说法是 leave, vacation, dismissal 等。

summary.en: Congestion means overcrowding or blockage (especially traffic), or a medical blockage like a stuffy nose.
summary.zh: Congestion 指拥堵/堵塞（常指交通），也可指医学上的堵塞，如鼻塞。

definition.en: (Correct spelling: congestion) A condition in which something (like traffic or a system) is too crowded or blocked, so movement becomes slow or difficult.
definition.zh: （正确拼写：congestion）拥堵；堵塞（指交通或系统过于拥挤或被阻塞，导致通行缓慢或困难）。

examples.en: There was heavy traffic congestion during rush hour.
examples.zh: 高峰时段交通严重拥堵。

examples.en: We need to fix the road design to reduce congestion downtown.
examples.zh: 我们需要改善道路设计来减少市中心的拥堵。

examples.en: The accident caused congestion on the highway for miles.
examples.zh: 这起事故导致高速公路拥堵了好几英里。

definition.en: In medicine, an unhealthy buildup of blood or fluid in a body part, often causing swelling or a blocked feeling (especially in the nose or chest).
definition.zh: （医学）充血；鼻塞/胸闷（血液或体液在身体某部位异常积聚，常引起肿胀或堵塞感）。

examples.en: He has nasal congestion from a cold.
examples.zh: 他因为感冒而鼻塞。

examples.en: Warm steam can help relieve congestion.
examples.zh: 热蒸汽可以帮助缓解鼻塞。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“congession”常见原因是把 -st- 的拼写漏掉了；标准拼写是 congestion。可以把它拆开记：con-（一起）+ gest（堆积）+ -ion（名词后缀），整体就是“堆在一起导致堵塞”。

summary.en: “Congest” means to crowd or block a place (especially roads) or to cause nasal blockage from illness or allergies.
summary.zh: “congest”指（使）拥堵/堵塞（常指交通），也可指因感冒或过敏导致鼻塞、充血。

definition.en: to become or make something too crowded or blocked, especially a road or area with too many vehicles or people
definition.zh: （使）拥堵；（使）堵塞（尤指道路、区域因车辆或人太多而不通畅）

examples.en: Morning traffic often congests the highway near downtown.
examples.zh: 早高峰时，市中心附近的高速公路常常会拥堵。

examples.en: Too many trucks can congest the narrow streets.
examples.zh: 卡车太多会把狭窄的街道堵得水泄不通。

definition.en: to become blocked because of too much mucus, making it hard to breathe through the nose (often used with “be” or “get”)
definition.zh: （鼻子等）充血、堵塞（因分泌物过多而不通畅，常与 be/get 连用）

examples.en: I get congested when my allergies are bad.
examples.zh: 过敏严重时我就会鼻塞。

examples.en: The cold left him congested for a week.
examples.zh: 这次感冒让他鼻塞了一周。

extraExplanation: “congest”在交通语境里很常见，常与traffic/roads/streets/highway搭配：traffic is congested（交通很拥堵）；也可以说congested roads（拥堵的道路）。
健康语境里更常见的形容词是“congested”（鼻塞的、充血的），名词是“congestion”（拥堵/鼻塞）。
同义表达：交通—jam, clog, back up；鼻塞—stuffy, blocked nose。

summary.en: “Congested” means overcrowded or blocked, making movement or flow difficult (traffic, places, or your nose).
summary.zh: “congested”表示拥挤或堵塞，导致通行或流动困难（如交通、场所或鼻塞）。

definition.en: Too crowded or full, so movement or flow becomes slow or difficult (often about roads, places, or body parts like the nose).
definition.zh: 过于拥挤或堵塞，导致通行或流动变慢或困难（常指道路、场所，或身体部位如鼻子）。

examples.en: The streets are congested during rush hour.
examples.zh: 高峰期街道很拥堵。

examples.en: I can’t breathe well because my nose is congested.
examples.zh: 我鼻子堵得厉害，呼吸不太顺。

examples.en: The hospital was congested with patients after the accident.
examples.zh: 事故发生后，医院挤满了病人。

definition.en: Related to congestion: a blocked or overfilled condition (especially in medical or technical contexts).
definition.zh: 与“充血/阻塞/拥塞”有关的（尤用于医学或技术语境）。

examples.en: The doctor listened to his congested lungs.
examples.zh: 医生听诊了他充血、堵塞的肺部。

examples.en: Use the report to identify congested network areas.
examples.zh: 用这份报告来找出网络拥塞的区域。

extraExplanation: “congested”来自动词“congest”（使拥塞/使充满），常见搭配有：congested roads/traffic（拥堵的道路/交通）、congested city streets（拥挤的城市街道）、congested nose/sinuses（鼻塞/鼻窦堵塞）、congested lungs（肺部充血/淤积）。
日常口语中形容交通更常说“traffic is heavy”或“it’s really backed up”。医学鼻塞也常说“stuffy nose”。

summary.en: “Congestedness” means the state of being congested (blocked or overcrowded), though “congestion” is more common.
summary.zh: “congestedness”指“拥堵/阻塞的状态”，但更常用的词是“congestion”。

definition.en: The state or quality of being congested; heaviness or blockage caused by too much traffic, too many people, or too much fluid/mucus (in the body).
definition.zh: 拥堵/阻塞的状态或性质；因交通、人群过多，或（身体）液体/黏液积聚而造成的堵塞、憋胀感。

examples.en: During rush hour, the downtown streets show extreme congestedness.
examples.zh: 在高峰时段，市中心街道拥堵得很严重。

examples.en: The doctor asked about his nasal congestedness and trouble breathing at night.
examples.zh: 医生询问他鼻塞的情况以及夜间呼吸困难的问题。

extraExplanation: “congestedness”在现代英语中比较少见，很多时候更常用、更自然的说法是“congestion”（拥堵/充血/鼻塞）或“crowding/traffic congestion”（人群/交通拥堵）。在医学语境也常用“nasal congestion”（鼻塞）。
构词：congested（拥堵的/充血的）+ -ness（名词后缀，表示“……的状态/性质”）。因此它强调“处于拥堵/阻塞的状态”。

summary.en: “Congestible” means able to become blocked or medically congested.
summary.zh: “congestible”表示“可变得堵塞或（医学上）可发生充血/淤塞的”。

definition.en: able to become congested (blocked or crowded), especially in a medical sense (e.g., tissues, lungs, blood vessels).
definition.zh: 可发生充血或阻塞的；（尤指医学上）容易变得淤塞/拥堵的（如组织、肺部、血管）。

examples.en: People with asthma may have more congestible airways during a cold.
examples.zh: 哮喘患者在感冒时气道可能更容易出现淤塞。

examples.en: Inflamed nasal tissue is highly congestible, which is why your nose can feel suddenly blocked.
examples.zh: 发炎的鼻腔组织很容易充血肿胀，所以鼻子会突然感觉堵住。

extraExplanation: “congestible”在日常英语中不算常用，更常见的是用“congested（充血的/堵塞的）”或“prone to congestion（容易堵塞/充血的）”。
词根提示：congest- 来自“congestion（拥堵；充血）”，后缀 -ible 表示“能够……的”。多见于医学或技术性写作中。

summary.en: “Congesting” means becoming or causing something to become crowded/blocked (traffic) or blocked in the body (medical congestion).
summary.zh: “Congesting”指正在变得或正在造成拥堵/堵塞（交通），或引起身体（如鼻子、胸部）的充血/阻塞。

definition.en: becoming crowded, blocked, or overfilled (often about traffic or roads)
definition.zh: 变得拥挤、堵塞或过度挤满（常指交通、道路）

examples.en: Cars were congesting the highway during rush hour.
examples.zh: 在高峰期，汽车把高速公路堵得水泄不通。

examples.en: New construction is congesting the downtown streets.
examples.zh: 新的施工让市中心街道变得更堵了。

definition.en: causing congestion in the body (a buildup that blocks normal flow, especially in the nose, chest, or lungs)
definition.zh: 使身体出现“充血/阻塞”（尤其指鼻子、胸部或肺部的堵塞、痰多等）

examples.en: A cold can leave you congesting your nose and sinuses.
examples.zh: 感冒可能会让你的鼻子和鼻窦变得堵塞。

examples.en: The smoke was congesting his chest, making it hard to breathe.
examples.zh: 烟雾让他的胸口发闷堵塞，呼吸变得困难。

extraExplanation: “congesting”是动词congest的现在分词/动名词形式，常用在进行时（is/are congesting）或作定语（congesting traffic）。更常见的形容状态表达是“congested”（e.g., congested roads / congested nose）。
交通语境里：congest = 使（道路/区域）拥堵；医学语境里：congest = 使（器官/通道）充血或堵塞。日常说“鼻塞”更常用be congested或have congestion。

summary.en: Congestion means overcrowding that causes delay (often traffic) or blockage/too much fluid in the body (often nose or chest).
summary.zh: Congestion 指因过度拥挤导致的拥堵/延误（常见于交通），也指身体部位（常为鼻或胸）堵塞或充血、积液造成的不适。

definition.en: A situation in which something (especially traffic) is too crowded, causing slow movement or delay.
definition.zh: （尤指交通）拥堵；因过于拥挤而导致移动缓慢或延误的情况。

examples.en: There was heavy traffic congestion on the highway this morning.
examples.zh: 今天早上高速公路上交通严重拥堵。

examples.en: The city is trying to reduce congestion by improving public transportation.
examples.zh: 这座城市正通过改善公共交通来减少拥堵。

definition.en: A medical condition in which a part of the body (often the nose or lungs) becomes blocked or filled with fluid, making it hard to breathe.
definition.zh: （医学）充血；（常指鼻/肺）堵塞或积液，导致呼吸不畅。

examples.en: I have nasal congestion from a cold.
examples.zh: 我感冒了，鼻子很堵。

examples.en: The doctor listened to his chest for signs of congestion.
examples.zh: 医生听了他的胸部，检查是否有充血（或肺部淤积）的迹象。

extraExplanation: 在英语里，congestion 常见两大语境：1）交通（traffic congestion）；2）健康/医学（nasal congestion, chest congestion）。日常口语里说“鼻塞”更常用 nasal congestion 或直接说 a stuffy nose。
常见搭配：relieve congestion（缓解堵塞/充血），cause congestion（造成拥堵），ease congestion（缓解拥堵），congestion pricing（拥堵收费：在高峰期对进入特定区域的车辆收费以减少车流）。

summary.en: “Congestions” is the plural of “congestion,” meaning bodily blockage (like a stuffy nose) or overcrowding—especially traffic jams.
summary.zh: “congestions”是“congestion”的复数，可指身体堵塞（如鼻塞/胸闷）或（尤指交通）拥堵、拥挤。

definition.en: blockage or swelling in the body (especially the nose or chest) caused by too much fluid or mucus
definition.zh: （尤指鼻子或胸部的）充血、堵塞；（因黏液或体液过多导致的）鼻塞/胸闷

examples.en: I have nasal congestion, so it’s hard to breathe through my nose.
examples.zh: 我鼻塞，所以很难用鼻子呼吸。

examples.en: The doctor asked if she had any chest congestion or coughing.
examples.zh: 医生问她有没有胸闷（胸部堵塞感）或咳嗽。

definition.en: a situation where a road or place is too crowded, causing slow movement (especially traffic)
definition.zh: （尤指交通）拥堵；（道路/场所）过于拥挤导致通行缓慢

examples.en: Morning traffic congestions often make the commute longer.
examples.zh: 早高峰的交通拥堵常常让通勤时间变长。

examples.en: The city is trying to reduce congestion by improving public transportation.
examples.zh: 这座城市正通过改善公共交通来减少拥堵。

definition.en: overcrowding or too much of something in one area (more general use)
definition.zh: （更泛指）拥挤；过度集中；堆积

examples.en: There was congestion near the entrance because everyone arrived at once.
examples.zh: 入口附近很拥挤，因为大家同时到达。

extraExplanation: “congestions”是“congestion”的复数，但在很多场景里“congestion”常作不可数名词使用（如 traffic congestion, nasal congestion）。当你在新闻或报告里看到“congestions”，通常是在指“多处/多种拥堵或堵塞情况”。
医学语境中常见搭配：nasal congestion（鼻塞）、chest congestion（胸部堵塞感/痰多）。交通语境中更常说 traffic congestion（交通拥堵），也常用动词缓解表达：ease/reduce congestion（缓解/减少拥堵）。

summary.en: Congestive means “causing or related to congestion,” and is often used in medical contexts (e.g., congestive heart failure).
summary.zh: congestive 表示“引起或与淤塞/充血有关的”，常用于医学语境（如“充血性心力衰竭”）。

definition.en: Too full or blocked, especially in the nose, lungs, or blood vessels; causing or related to congestion.
definition.zh: （尤指鼻腔、肺或血管）充血的、淤塞的；与（鼻塞/充血/阻塞）有关的。

examples.en: I have a congestive cough and feel pressure in my chest.
examples.zh: 我咳得很厉害（带痰、堵），而且胸口有压迫感。

examples.en: A cold can make your nose congestive at night.
examples.zh: 感冒会让你晚上鼻子更堵。

definition.en: Used in medical terms to describe a condition involving fluid buildup or impaired circulation, especially in the heart.
definition.zh: （医学用语）用于描述与体液潴留或循环不良有关的情况，尤指心脏方面。

examples.en: The doctor mentioned congestive heart failure as a possible diagnosis.
examples.zh: 医生提到“充血性心力衰竭”可能是一个诊断方向。

examples.en: Congestive symptoms can include swelling in the legs and shortness of breath.
examples.zh: 充血性（循环不良）症状可能包括腿部水肿和呼吸急促。

extraExplanation: “congestive”常见于医学搭配，最典型的是 congestive heart failure（充血性心力衰竭，简称 CHF）。在日常表达里，更常说 “congested” 来形容“鼻塞/堵”：I’m congested. / a congested nose。
词根提示：con-（一起）+ gest（携带/堆积）→ “堆在一起、挤在一起”→ 引申为“淤塞、充血”。

summary.en: “Congests” means becomes blocked or crowded (traffic/places) or becomes blocked with fluid (the body).
summary.zh: “Congests”表示变得拥堵、堵塞（交通/场所），也可指身体因充血或积液而堵塞。

definition.en: (of a place, road, or system) to become blocked or crowded so that movement becomes slow or difficult; third-person singular of “congest.”
definition.zh: （地方、道路或系统）变得拥堵、堵塞，使通行变慢或困难；为动词“congest”的第三人称单数形式。

examples.en: The highway congests during rush hour.
examples.zh: 高峰期这条高速公路会拥堵。

examples.en: When too many people arrive at once, the entrance congests quickly.
examples.zh: 当太多人同时到达时，入口很快就会被挤堵。

examples.en: This narrow street congests easily after school.
examples.zh: 这条狭窄的街道放学后很容易堵。

definition.en: (of the body) to become filled with too much blood or fluid, causing swelling or a “blocked” feeling (often used for the nose, chest, or lungs).
definition.zh: （身体）充血或积液过多而出现肿胀、堵塞感（常指鼻子、胸部或肺部）。

examples.en: My nose congests when the weather changes.
examples.zh: 天气变化时我鼻子会堵。

examples.en: In some illnesses, the lungs can congest with fluid.
examples.zh: 在某些疾病中，肺部可能会因积液而淤塞。

extraExplanation: “congests”是“congest”的第三人称单数（he/she/it congests）。常见搭配：traffic congests（交通拥堵）、streets congest（街道堵塞）、nose congests（鼻子堵）。日常说“鼻塞”更常用 be congested / nasal congestion。

summary.en: “Congestus” is mainly used in meteorology to mean a towering cumulus cloud (cumulus congestus).
summary.zh: “Congestus”主要用于气象领域，指塔状积云（cumulus congestus，垂直发展强的积云）。

definition.en: (Meteorology) A type of cumulus cloud with strong vertical growth (a tall, cauliflower-shaped “towering cumulus”), often a sign of rising warm, moist air and potential showers.
definition.zh: （气象）一种垂直发展很强的积云（高耸、呈“花椰菜状”的塔状积云），常表示暖湿空气强烈上升，可能带来阵雨。

examples.en: By late afternoon, cumulus congestus clouds were building over the hills.
examples.zh: 到傍晚时，山丘上空开始堆积起塔状积云。

examples.en: Pilots watch for congestus because it can signal developing thunderstorms nearby.
examples.zh: 飞行员会留意塔状积云，因为它可能预示附近正在发展雷暴。

definition.en: (Less common) Describing clouds that are piled up or heaped together, especially in the phrase “cumulus congestus.”
definition.zh: （较少见）形容云层“堆积、聚集”的，尤用于短语“cumulus congestus（塔状积云）”。

examples.en: The forecast mentioned cumulus congestus forming after midday heating.
examples.zh: 预报提到在午后增温后会形成塔状积云。

extraExplanation: “Congestus”源自拉丁语，意为“堆积起来的、聚集的”。在英语里它最常见于云的分类：**cumulus congestus**，中文常译为“塔状积云”或“浓积云”（不同资料可能略有差异）。它通常比普通积云更高、更厚，但还没有发展到成熟的积雨云（cumulonimbus）。

summary.en: “Congiaries” is the plural of “congiary,” meaning public gifts or handouts (money or goods), especially in ancient Rome.
summary.zh: “congiaries”是“congiary”的复数，指公开发放的赏赐/救济（钱或物资），尤见于古罗马语境。

definition.en: a gift of money, grain, or other goods given publicly (especially in ancient Rome) by a ruler or government to the people; plural: congiaries
definition.zh: （尤指古罗马统治者或政府）向民众公开发放的赏赐、施舍或救济（如钱、粮食等）；复数：congiaries

examples.en: The emperor won popularity by distributing congiaries to the urban poor.
examples.zh: 皇帝通过向城市贫民发放congiaries来赢得民心。

examples.en: Historical records describe congiaries of grain during times of shortage.
examples.zh: 史料记载，在短缺时期曾发放以谷物为主的congiaries。

extraExplanation: “congiary”源自拉丁语 congiarium，原指按“congius（古罗马的容量单位）”计量发放的酒或油，后来引申为统治者向民众发放的金钱或物资。它常用于历史写作，带有“政治性施恩/笼络民心”的语感。

summary.en: A congiary is a (usually public) gift or distribution of goods or money, especially in ancient Rome.
summary.zh: congiary 指（通常公开的）赏赐或物资/金钱的发放，尤常用于古罗马语境。

definition.en: a gift or public distribution of money, food, or other goods (especially in ancient Rome, given by an emperor or a political leader to the people)
definition.zh: （尤指古罗马）统治者或政治领袖向民众发放的赏赐/施舍（如金钱、粮食等）

examples.en: The new emperor announced a congiary to celebrate his accession.
examples.zh: 新皇帝宣布发放赏赐，以庆祝他即位。

examples.en: Historians describe a congiary of grain during a time of shortage.
examples.zh: 历史学家记载了在短缺时期一次发放粮食的赏赐。

definition.en: any generous gift or donation (formal, rare)
definition.zh: （正式用语，较少见）慷慨的赠与/捐赠

examples.en: The library received a congiary of rare books from a private collector.
examples.zh: 图书馆收到一位私人收藏家捐赠的一批珍贵书籍。

extraExplanation: “congiary”多见于历史或文学语境，常与古罗马的公共政治生活相关：统治者通过向民众发放钱粮来赢得支持、庆祝胜利或稳定局势。
词源与拉丁语有关：原指按“congius（量器）”计量分发的酒或油，后来引申为“按份发放的赏赐”。
拼写提示：也常见变体“congiarium”（更偏拉丁原形、历史写法）。

summary.en: Congee is a thick rice porridge, often eaten for breakfast and served with savory toppings.
summary.zh: Congee 指稠米粥/稀饭，常作早餐，可搭配各种咸味配料。

definition.en: a thick rice porridge (often eaten for breakfast), usually served plain or with savory toppings like meat, fish, eggs, or pickles
definition.zh: （常作早餐的）稠米粥/稀饭，常配肉、鱼、蛋、腌菜等咸味配料一起吃

examples.en: I usually eat congee when I want something warm and easy to digest.
examples.zh: 我想吃点暖和、好消化的东西时，通常会喝粥。

examples.en: The restaurant serves congee with chicken and ginger.
examples.zh: 这家餐厅的粥会配鸡肉和姜。

extraExplanation: 你输入的“congii”在英语里不常见，最可能是拼写想写 **congee**（米粥）。在不同地区也常见写法/称呼：粤语常说 **jook**，闽南/台湾语境常见“稀饭”，普通话常说“粥”。
词源上，congee 来自葡萄牙语 *canja*（意为米粥/鸡粥），与亚洲多地饮食交流有关。

summary.en: Congius is a rare historical word meaning an ancient Roman unit for measuring liquids.
summary.zh: Congius 是一个较罕见的历史词，指古罗马用于计量液体的容量单位。

definition.en: a unit of liquid measure in ancient Rome (about 3.3–3.5 liters, roughly 0.9 US gallons).
definition.zh: （古罗马）液体容量单位（约3.3–3.5升，约0.9美制加仑）。

examples.en: In ancient Rome, a congius was used to measure wine and other liquids.
examples.zh: 在古罗马，congius 常用来计量葡萄酒等液体。

examples.en: The inscription mentions a congius, showing the container’s standard size.
examples.zh: 铭文中提到 congius，说明这个容器有标准容量。

extraExplanation: 这个词在现代英语里非常罕见，多见于历史、考古、古典学（Latin/Roman studies）或博物馆说明文字中。
congius 源自拉丁语，是罗马计量体系的一部分；不同资料会给出略有差异的现代换算值（大约3.3到3.5升），因为古代标准在不同时期/地区可能不完全一致。
如果你本来想查的是常见英语单词，可能是拼写有误；你可以告诉我上下文句子，我也可以帮你确认是否想表达 “conscious / congenial / congeal”等。

summary.en: “Conglaciate” means to freeze or turn into ice (or to cause something to do so). It is rare and more formal than “freeze.”
summary.zh: “Conglaciate”表示“冻结、结成冰（或使之结冰）”。它很少见，语气比 freeze 更正式/书面。

definition.en: (Intransitive) To freeze or become solid, especially by turning into ice; to congeal.
definition.zh: （不及物）冻结、凝固；尤指结成冰。

examples.en: As temperatures fell overnight, the slush began to conglaciate into a thin sheet of ice.
examples.zh: 夜里气温下降后，雪泥开始冻结成一层薄冰。

examples.en: Moisture on the rocks can conglaciate quickly in strong wind.
examples.zh: 岩石上的水汽在强风中会很快凝结成冰。

definition.en: (Transitive) To freeze (something) or cause it to congeal into ice.
definition.zh: （及物）使（某物）冻结；使凝结成冰。

examples.en: A sudden cold snap conglaciated the puddles across the path.
examples.zh: 一阵突然的寒潮使小路上的水坑都结了冰。

examples.en: The high-altitude air can conglaciate wet clothing within minutes.
examples.zh: 高海拔的空气能在几分钟内把湿衣服冻硬。

extraExplanation: 这是一个非常少见、偏文学或科学写作风格的词，日常英语里更常用 freeze（冻结）或 congeal（凝固）。
词根来自拉丁语 glacies（冰），所以它带有“变成冰/形成冰”的感觉；在地质、气候或描写寒冷环境的文字中更可能出现。

summary.en: Conglobate means to form or gather into a rounded mass; it can also describe something that is clustered into a ball-like shape.
summary.zh: conglobate 指“聚成团/卷成球状”，也可形容“团状聚集的”。

definition.en: to gather, roll, or form into a rounded mass (like a ball); to clump together
definition.zh: 把……聚成团；卷成球状；使凝结成一团

examples.en: Dust and fibers can conglobate into small balls under a sofa.
examples.zh: 灰尘和纤维会在沙发底下凝结成小团。

examples.en: Over time, the wet sand conglobated into lumps that were easy to pick up.
examples.zh: 时间久了，湿沙会聚成容易捡起的块状。

definition.en: (of things) gathered into a rounded mass; clustered together
definition.zh: （事物）聚成团的；球状聚集的

examples.en: The microscope showed conglobate clusters of cells.
examples.zh: 显微镜显示细胞呈团状聚集。

extraExplanation: “conglobate”比较少见，更常见的表达是“clump together / form a ball / cluster”。它来自拉丁语 conglobare（con- ‘一起’ + globus ‘球’），字面意思是“聚成球”。在科学写作（如生物、医学、材料学）里偶尔会用来描述“团簇/聚集成团”的形态。

summary.en: “Conglobated” is a rare word meaning “clustered or formed into a rounded mass,” or it can be the past form of “conglobate.”
summary.zh: “conglobated”较罕见，意思是“聚成团/凝成球状”，也可作动词“conglobate”的过去式/过去分词。

definition.en: (rare) Formed into a rounded mass; clustered together like a ball or lump.
definition.zh: （罕见）聚成团的；凝成球状或一团的。

examples.en: Dark clouds conglobated above the hills, promising rain.
examples.zh: 乌云在山丘上空聚成一团，预示着要下雨。

examples.en: Dust had conglobated in the corner of the room.
examples.zh: 灰尘在房间角落里结成了一团。

definition.en: Past tense / past participle of “conglobate”: to gather or form into a rounded mass; to cluster.
definition.zh: “conglobate”的过去式/过去分词：使聚成团；（使）凝成球状；聚集。

examples.en: Moisture conglobated the fine powder into small lumps.
examples.zh: 水分使细粉末凝结成一个个小团块。

examples.en: Over time, the small groups conglobated into a single movement.
examples.zh: 随着时间推移，这些小团体逐渐聚合成一个统一的运动。

extraExplanation: 这个词在现代英语里非常少见，更常见的表达是 clumped (结块的/成团的)、clustered (聚集的)、gathered (聚拢的)。
词源来自拉丁语 con-（一起）+ globus（球、圆团），字面意思就是“聚成球/团”。在文学或较旧的科学写作中偶尔能见到。

summary.en: Conglobately means “in a clustered or ball-like way,” but it’s rare in modern English.
summary.zh: conglobately 意为“呈团聚/球状聚集地”，但在现代英语中很少用。

definition.en: In a rounded, ball-like, or clustered way; gathered into a compact mass.
definition.zh: 以（球状）团聚的方式；聚成一团、聚合成紧密的一团。

examples.en: The dust collected conglobately in the corners of the room.
examples.zh: 灰尘在房间角落里呈团状聚集。

examples.en: Cells may grow conglobately, forming a small lump.
examples.zh: 细胞可能会呈团块状生长，形成一个小结节。

extraExplanation: 这个词非常少见，更多时候会用更常见的表达来替代，例如：in clusters（成簇地）、in a lump（成团地）、in a ball（成球状地）、compactly（紧密地）。
词根来自拉丁语 con-（共同、一起）+ globus（球、团），相关词有 conglobate（使聚成团/球状；团块状的）与 globular（球状的）。
在现代英语里，它偶尔出现在医学或生物学语境中，用来描述“团块/结节样”聚集的形态（如 conglobate acne 常译为“聚合性痤疮”）。

summary.en: “Conglobating” means forming or gathering into a rounded mass (clumping into a ball-like shape).
summary.zh: “Conglobating”表示“聚成一团/凝成球状或团块状”，常用于较正式或科学语境。

definition.en: forming or gathering into a rounded mass; rolling or grouping things into a ball-like shape
definition.zh: 使（或正在）聚成一团；凝结成球状（或团块状）

examples.en: Dust was conglobating in the corners of the room.
examples.zh: 灰尘正在房间的角落里聚成一团。

examples.en: As the syrup cooled, it began conglobating into thick lumps.
examples.zh: 糖浆冷却后开始凝成一块块黏稠的团块。

definition.en: clustered or rounded into a mass; ball-shaped (describing a group or shape)
definition.zh: 成团的；球状的（用来描述聚集或外形）

examples.en: They found conglobating clouds on the horizon, signaling a storm.
examples.zh: 他们看到地平线处云层成团聚集，预示着暴风雨。

extraExplanation: “conglobating”来自动词 conglobate（con- 表“共同/一起” + glob “球/团块”）。在现代英语里它比较少见，更常用的表达是 “clumping together / forming into a ball / gathering into a mass”。
在科学或较正式的写作中，它可能用来描述颗粒、细胞或物质“凝聚成团”的过程。日常口语中一般不用这个词。

summary.en: Conglobation means gathering into a mass/ball, or (in rhetoric) piling up points for emphasis.
summary.zh: Conglobation 指“聚成一团/一球”，也可指（修辞）“把论据集中堆叠以强调”。

definition.en: the act or process of gathering things together into a rounded mass or ball; clumping into a single whole
definition.zh: 把事物聚拢成团、成球或成一团块的过程；凝聚成整体

examples.en: Dust and hair can form a conglobation under the bed.
examples.zh: 灰尘和头发可能会在床底下聚成一团。

examples.en: The report described the conglobation of cells into a small lump.
examples.zh: 报告描述了细胞聚集成一个小肿块（小团块）。

definition.en: (rhetoric) the piling up or grouping of arguments, examples, or descriptions for emphasis; an accumulation
definition.zh: （修辞）为加强语气而把论点、例子或描述层层堆叠、集中罗列；累积

examples.en: The speaker used conglobation, listing problem after problem to build urgency.
examples.zh: 演讲者用了“层层堆叠”的方式，一个问题接一个问题地列出，营造紧迫感。

examples.en: In persuasive writing, conglobation can make a point feel overwhelming.
examples.zh: 在说服性写作中，这种“集中罗列”能让观点显得更有压迫感、更难反驳。

extraExplanation: 词源提示：来自拉丁语 con-（一起）+ globus（球、团）。因此它的核心画面感就是“聚成一个球/一团”。
